title: Chromatic Pool
listingDescription: A hydrothermal pool in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: A hot spring with yellow around the edges and green in the center sits in a hydrothermal basin.
images.title: Chromatic Pool

bodyText:
Chromatic Pool is closely related to neighboring Beauty Pool, which shows its brightest colors when its water is hottest. During periodic energy shifts, the level of one spring rises as the other lowers. Chromatic Pool has an average temperate of 133.1°F (56.2°C), an average pH of 8.5, and an average conductivity of 2096 uS/cm.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Chromatic Pool 534 words There are 4 sections in this description. Section 1 (127 words) You are facing Chromatic Pool, which is connected to nearby Beauty Pool. Both pools are located in the Upper Geyser Basin. These pools, or hot springs, share similar colors--yellowish-brown on their wide periphery with deep bluish-green centers. Standing to the side of the boardwalk leading in front of the two pools is a wayside entitled “Beauty and Chromatic Pools.” Text below the title tells us: “Living Color. The vivid colors of Beauty Pool's basin and runoff channels are created by microscopic lifeforms. Incredibly, these organisms survive and thrive in an environment that would be lethal to us and most other living creatures. Scientists are just beginning to understand these lifeforms; amazingly, hot spring environments may sustain a diversity of organisms rivaling that of terrestrial rain forests.” Section 2 (135 words) The first of two color photos below this text is captioned “Chromatic Pool” and shows a round dark bluish-brown pool surrounded on all sides by ground dusted with white geyserite. The second photo is captioned “Beauty Pool” and features a more oval-shaped pool, yellowish-brown on its periphery with a darker blue-gray center. A title below the photos reads: “Thermal Feature Color Gradient.” The corresponding text tells us: “In the geyser basins with alkaline or neutral pH (Upper, Midway, Lower, West Thumb, and Mammoth Hot Springs), color is primarily a function of what lives and grows in a feature. The graph to the right represents the upper environmental temperature limits for life and the corresponding colors (which vary over the course of a year as a consequence of seasonal changes) in the features or runoff channels.” Section 3 (107 words) The graph shows bright blue on its leftmost end, followed by white, bright yellow, green, pale brown, and dark brown. Text accompanied by an arrow pointing to the blue section reads: “Blue and clear waters are extremely hot and at times may exceed the boiling point (199 degrees Fahrenheit (93 degrees Centigrade) at this elevation.)” Other arrows pointing to the remaining colors--also representing water that decreases in temperature from 163 degrees to finally 60 degrees Fahrenheit as we move toward the far right end of the graph--indicate that various organisms such as fungi, algae, protozoa, mosses, crustaceans, insects, and trout can live in these pools. Section 4 (139 words) To the right of the photos is a drawing showing the underground water circulation here at the two pools, with a black arrow pointing downward into Chromatic Pool and another arrow pointing upward from inside Beauty Pool. A title below this drawing is “Hidden Connections.” Text below the title reads: “Beauty Pool shares an underground link with Chromatic Pool (to your immediate left). When Beauty Pool is full, Chromatic Pool's water level is much lower; sometimes the reverse may be observed. Many other features in the Upper Geyser Basin have demonstrated similar behavior. The factors affecting such exchanges of function are many and may include phenomena such as earthquakes and continuing mineral accumulations in each feature's underground ‘plumbing.’" A notation in the exhibit’s bottom right corner reads: “This exhibit made possible by a generous grant from the Yellowstone Association.” END OF MESSAGE

title: Churn Geyser
listingDescription: A hydrothermal pool in the Upper Geyser Basin
bodyText:
Churn Geyser is a large, clear pool with some geyserite deposits lining the edges and in the outwash channel of the pool. A deep vent sits in the center of the pool and the rest of the pool is shallow with orange thermophiles lining the edge and continuing into the outwash channel. Recently, Churn Geyser's activity seems to be related to activity cycles of Sawmill Geyser and other geysers in the Sawmill complex, with eruption intervals in the 5–20 minute range.

Churn Geyser has an average temperate of 168.9°F (76°C), an average pH of 7.4, and an average conductivity of 2102 uS/cm.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Churn Geyser is a large, clear pool with some geyserite deposits lining the edges and in the outwash channel of the pool. A deep vent sits in the center of the pool and the rest of the pool is shallow with orange thermophiles lining the edge and continuing into the outwash channel.

title: Churning Caldron

images.altText: People stand on the boardwalk and watch the activity of the hot spring.
images.caption: Visitors at Churning Caldron

bodyText: A large hot spring located near the top of the Mud Volcano area.

title: Cistern Spring

images.altText: A turquoise pool of water bubbles, surrounded by dead tree stumps with white at their base
images.caption: Hot spring and dead trees

bodyText:
Cistern Spring and Steamboat Geyser are linked underground, confirmed in 1983 when Cistern Spring began emptying after each major eruption of Steamboat.

Otherwise, Cistern Spring is a blue or green pol with constant overflow. Its waters deposit as much as half and inch of sinter a year. Look at the trees around and below this spring. The silica-rich water of Cistern Spring has killed many of them.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Color and Heat Lovers

Hydrothermal features are also habitats in which microscopic organisms survive and thrive. They are called thermophiles: "thermo" for heat and "phile" for lover.

Although they are too small to be seen with the naked eye, trillions are grouped together and appear as masses of color. They are nourished by energy and chemical building blocks.

Colorless and yellow thermophiles grow in the hottest water.

Orange, brown, and green thermophiles grow in cooler waters.

Imagine living in near-boiling temperatures, in hydrothermal features with the alkalinity of baking soda, or in water so acidic that it can burn holes in clothing. Microorganisms in Yellowstone need these extremes to survive.

Norris Geyser Basin

Norris Geyser Basin is one of the hottest and most acidic of Yellowstone’s hydrothermal areas. It is outside of the most recent Yellowstone caldera, but inside the first and largest caldera. It sits on the intersection of three major faults and is a very active earthquake area.

Each year, new hot springs and geysers appear while others become dormant. Geologic events trigger many of these changes. Even small earthquakes can alter hydrothermal behavior. This sudden activity is known as a “thermal disturbance” and can last a few days, or more than a week. Gradually, most features return to “normal.”

No one fully understands why this happens. Norris has the greatest water chemistry diversity among Yellowstone’s hydrothermal areas. The water chemistry changes as the water levels of underground hot water reservoirs fluctuates.

Although Norris is known for its acid features, it also have alkaline hot springs and geysers. As underground water and chemistry shift suddenly, they could contribute to dramatic changes in minerals and pH.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription:
Cistern Spring
437 words
There are 2 sections in this description.
Section 1 (121 words)
You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit located alongside the boardwalk trail leading to Cistern Spring. The wayside is entitled "Norris Geyser Basin: Underground Network." Text below the title tells us:

"Imagine a network of water-filled channels below you-Norris Geyser Basin's uncharted â€˜plumbing system.' Geysers and hot springs reveal clues about their underground connections.

"After a major eruption, Steamboat Geyser ejects a massive steam column well beyond the treetops for many hours. Typically, nearby Cistern Spring drains, then refills several days later."

At the top of the panel is a small color photo showing a tall column of steam rising from a distant geyser. The caption reads:

"Steam phase following Steamboat Geyser's major eruption on May 2, 2000."

Section 2 (298 words)

On the panel's right side is a map drawing with Back Basin labeled in its center and the smaller Porcelain Basin located to Back Basin's north, at the top of the map. A red dot with the words "You Are Here" indicates your position alongside Cistern Spring on the eastern periphery of Back Basin. You are standing at the junction of two boardwalks, one that leads northeast to Steamboat Geyser and the other leading due west toward Veteran Geyser.

Additional boardwalks and dirt or paved trails lead past other hydrothermal features including Echinus Geyser and Arch Steam Vent to the southeast and southwest respectively, before continuing further west to Puff â€˜n Stuff Geyser, Black Hermit Caldron, and Green Dragon Spring at the bottom of the map.

The trail to the north of Green Dragon Spring leads to Blue Mud Steam Vent, Yellow Funnel Spring, Porkchop Geyser, Pearl Geyser, Vixen Geyser, Palpitator Spring, Fearless Geyser, Monarch Geyser and Minute Geyser; at the top of Back Basin the trail loops around to reach Emerald Spring, located due north of your position at Cistern Spring.

Note that there are 3 sets of restrooms located in the parking areas serving Norris Geyser Basin Museum. The museum is located north of Emerald Spring.

Finally, on the bottom of the panel are two color photos entitled "Cistern Spring." The photo on the left shows a crater only three-quarters full of water. The photo of the right shows an empty crater. The captions read:

"Cistern Spring began draining when Steamboat Geyser erupted on May 2, 2000.


"On the following morning, Cistern Spring was empty, exposing sinter-coated tree roots in the bottom of the spring."

A notation in the exhibit's bottom right corner reads: "This exhibit made possible by a generous grant from The Yellowstone Association."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Clear Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: This trailhead is located on the southeast side of the Uncle Tom's parking lot on the South Rim Drive of the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. From this trailhead, you can access the following trails:- Ribbon Lake Trail Ribbon Lake Trail An easy 5.8-mile (9.3-km) there-and-back trail. The trail traverses through forest with views of the Grand Canyon. CAUTION: Grizzly bears frequent this area. Backcountry RegulationsPermit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight

images.altText: A turquoise blue lake surrounded by a forest.
images.title: Clear Lake

bodyText:
This trailhead is located on the southeast side of the Uncle Tom's parking lot on the South Rim Drive of the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. From this trailhead, you can access the following trails:

  • Ribbon Lake Trail

Ribbon Lake Trail

Campfires allowed only in designated campsites within established fire rings. Extinguish campfires completely before leaving site. Follow LEAVE NO TRACE travel and camping techniques. Enjoy the backcountry and help keep it clean for others to enjoy. Bury human waste and toilet tissue in a 6–8 inch (15–18 cm) deep “cat hole” at least 100 feet (30 m) from water and trails. River Crossings. Park waters are swift and cold. Swimming in park rivers is not recommended. River crossings are hazardous. Lightning Safety. During thunderstorms, descend to lower elevation, avoid open areas and isolated tall trees. Assume lightning position: feet together, crouch on foam pad or sit on pack, hands over ears. Regulations. Leave What You Find: Do not collect anything from the park. No Pets: No pets on trail. Obtain service animal regulations at backcountry offices. No Hunting: No hunting or discharge of firearms. No Motorized Vehicles: No motorized vehicles on trails. Wheeled Vehicles Restricted: No bicycles, strollers, or wheeled vehicles (except wheelchairs), except where specified. In an emergency, dial 9-1-1 or contact the nearest ranger station. Animals are Dangerous. Do not approach or feed any animal. Bison and elk have injured people. Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves. Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals. Be Prepared for a Bear Encounter. Grizzly and black bears inhabit all of Yellowstone National Park. Be Alert. Watch for signs of bear activity: scratches in trees, tracks, scat, or dig sites. Avoid dead animals. Make Noise. Avoid surprising a bear by calling out and clapping your hands at regular intervals to make your presence known. Carry Bear Spray. Carry bear spray and know how to use it. Keep it immediately available, not inside your pack. Hike in Groups. Travel in groups of 3 or more is recommended. Stay with your group at all times. What to do if you encounter a bear. Stay calm, do not run. Quietly detour or back away; stop if this seems to agitate the bear. Stay at least 100 yards (91 m) from bears. Do NOT feed bears or other animals. What to do if a bear charges you. Stand still, do not run. Stand your ground and use your bear spray. Spray when the bear is 60 feet (18 m) away or closer. If a bear charges, it may be a bluff charge. What to do if a bear makes contact. Drop to the ground; play dead. Lie face down and clasp your hands over the back of your neck; stay still and silent. Wait several minutes after the bear leaves before getting up and leaving the area.

title: Cleopatra Spring

images.altText: A series of ledges stained shades of pink, yellow, and brown from hydrothermal water.
images.title: Cleopatra Spring

bodyText:
These terraces are like living sculptures, shaped by the volume of water, the slope of the ground, and objects in the water’s path. Travertine builds up rapidly here and causes the features to change quickly and constantly.

Some vents will clog completely, new vents may form, and old vents may reopen. Sometimes the water is concentrated in a few springs while at other times it may spread across many outlets.

In every case, water follows the path of least resistance, which could be above ground or underground. Scientists estimate that, at any given time, about 10 percent of the water in the Mammoth Hot Springs system is on the surface; the other 90 percent is underground.

Mammoth Hot Springs

A network of fractures and fissures form the plumbing system that allows hot water from underground to reach the surface at Mammoth Hot Springs. Small earthquakes may keep the plumbing open. The water comes from rain and snow falling on surrounding mountains and seeping deep into the earth where it is heated.

The volcanic heat source for Mammoth Hot Springs remains somewhat of a mystery. Scientists have proposed two sources: the large magma chamber underlying the Yellowstone Caldera or a smaller heat source closer to Mammoth.

For hundreds of years, Shoshone and Bannock people collected minerals from the Mammoth Hot Springs terraces for white paint.

Travertine Terraces

Travertine terraces are formed from limestone (calcium carbonate). Water rises through the limestone, carrying high amounts of dissolved calcium carbonate. At the surface, carbon dioxide is released and calcium carbonate is deposited, forming travertine, the chalky white rock of the terraces. Due to the rapid rate of deposition, these features constantly and quickly change.

Color & Heat Lovers

Hydrothermal features are also habitats in which microscopic organisms survive and thrive. They are called thermophiles: "thermo" for heat and "phile" for lover.

Although they are too small to be seen with the naked eye, trillions are grouped together and appear as masses of color. They are nourished by energy and chemical building blocks.

Colorless and yellow thermophiles grow in the hottest water.

Orange, brown, and green thermophiles grow in cooler waters.

Imagine living in near-boiling temperatures, in hydrothermal features with the alkalinity of baking soda, or in water so acidic that it can burn holes in clothing. Microorganisms in Yellowstone need these extremes to survive.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription:
Cleopatra Spring
552 words
There are 2 sections in this description.
Section 1 (383 words)
You are now part way up the Mammoth Hot Springs Terraces hillside, at a junction in the boardwalk near Cleopatra Terrace and Mound Terrace.
A wayside exhibit features a large color topographical map of a vast landscape encompassing travertine terraces and hot springs. In the map's center, a white dot accompanied with the words "You Are Here" indicates your position just south of Cleopatra Terrace, and north of Mound Terrace. Jupiter Terrace and Main Terrace are both located further south, on the left side of the map. Located downhill from you is Minerva Terrace.
Also labeled throughout the pale and largely non-forested terraces in the map's foreground are Canary Spring, Palette Spring, and Liberty Cap. Opal Terrace lies furthest east, at the bottom of the map. "Bunsen Peak," "Terrace Mountain," and "Clagett Butte" are labeled from left to right at the top of the map.

The trail running past Cleopatra Terrace is represented by a dashed yellow line, indicating " boardwalk or trail with steep grades or stairs." Other trail sections winding throughout the terraces are represented with a dashed red line, indicating "wheelchair accessible boardwalk or trail." Four trailheads are marked with a "self-guiding trail" icon, including three trailheads at the bottom of the hill, and one trailhead at the top. On the far right side of the map, northwest of Hymen Terrace, a hiking trail is marked "Beaver Ponds Trail: five-mile loop" with an arrow pointing north, or away from the terraces.
Pictured at the bottom of the map, and located to your east, is a road that runs south, curving west to Upper Terrace Loop Drive, or north, curving east to the visitor center. There are three restrooms: one is located just north of the terraces, its photograph pictured on the map. Restrooms can also be found in the Albright Visitor Center in Mammoth. Both of these restrooms are wheelchair accessible. The third restroom is an outhouse located in the parking lot near the entrance to the Upper Terrace Loop Drive.
There are also five parking areas located throughout the site-four along the road to your east and one alongside Upper Terrace Drive. Wheelchair icons appear at three of the parking areas along the road to your east, alongside the origin of the three trails leading into the terraces.

Section 2 (151 words)
Below the map, in the panel's bottom left corner, is a small color photo showing a wide fissure in cracked earth. The photo is captioned "Fragile Ground." More text tells us: "The ground is fragile. For your safety, stay on the boardwalk or paved trail."
To the right of the photo is a subtitle "Stay Safe and Protect Resources" followed by these five instructions highlighted with bullet points:
"Hot springs can burn you! Please do not touch the water.
"Stay on the boardwalk or paved trails at all times. The ground is fragile, and hot water may be hidden below.
"Expect steep grades and stairs.
"Do not smoke, litter, or takes pets on trails.
"Hot spring vents can easily become clogged. To protect them, never throw anything into the springs."
A notation in the panel's bottom right corner reads: "This exhibit made possible by a generous grant from the Yellowstone Association."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Clepsydra Geyser

images.altText: A geyser erupts from a small pool, spraying water and steam into the air.
images.title: Clepsydra Geyser

bodyText:
This nearly constant performer splashes from several vents and its steam can be seen throughout the Lower Geyser Basin. Its name is Greek for water clock, and was given because the geyser used to erupt regularly every three minutes. Since the 1959 Hebgen Lae Earthquake, however, Clepsydra erupts almost without pause. Sometimes it quits during Fountain Geyser's eruption.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Fountain Paint Pot Area

Hydrothermal features can be grouped into two general categories: those with a great deal of water (hot springs and geysers) and those with limited water (mudpots and fumaroles). Despite their structural similarities, no two features are exactly alike. All of these features occur in the Fountain Paint Pot area.

Thermus aquaticus, the thermophile that revolutionized DNA replication processes, was discovered in this area.

Lower Geyser Basin

The Lower Geyser Basin sits on unstable glacial gravel on top of solid rock. The jarring energy of an earthquake can make the gravel vibrate and shift position, and compact or fracture.

All these changes affect water supplies to hot springs. They might force muddy water to the surface, clouding existing pools or creating new ones. They might divert water from a pool, causing it to dry up. Water temperatures might also increase or decrease due to these subsurface changes.

In the days after the Hebgen Lake earthquake of 1959, all of these changes were observed in various springs of the Firehole River geyser basins. The epicenter (point of origin) of the quake was determined to be about 31 air miles (50 km) northwest of the Fountain Paint Pots area.

Great Fountain Geyser, on the Firehole Lake Drive, is the only geyser outside of the Old Faithful area with eruption forecasts.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.

title: Cliff Geyser
listingDescription: Cliff Geyser is a hydrothermal feature at Black Sand Basin.

images.altText: A small geyser erupts on the edge of a river flowing through a thermal basin.
images.title: Cliff Geyser

bodyText:
Cliff Geyser is a clear pool in a geyserite ring that sits along the river bank. Round, bulbous geyserite fills the ring and forms the outer edge, but outside the ring pea-sized geyserite covers the surface. Hard sinter covers the further surrounding area. Some orange thermophiles exist in the area where Cliff Geyser drains. While Cliff Geyser has a varied history, recently it seems to be following a cycle of draining, then minor eruptions while the area fills, eventually resulting in a major eruption, the pool drains and remains quiet for a period before starting the cycle again. The interval between cycles can be up to 35 minutes.

Cliff Geyser has an average temperate of 174.3°F (79.1°C), an average pH of 6.1, and an average conductivity of 2295 uS/cm.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.

Round, bulbous geyserite fills the ring and forms the outer edge, but outside the ring pea-sized geyserite covers the surface. Hard sinter covers the further surrounding area. Some orange thermophiles exist in the area where Cliff Geyser drains.

title: Colter / Wolverine Trailhead (8K8)
listingDescription: This is a remote trailhead at the southern boundary of the park that is not accessible by road. From this trailhead, you can embark on the following trails within the park:- Colter / Wolverine Trail- South Boundary Trail: South Entrance-Harebell- Snake River Cutoff Trail- Snake River Canyon Trail- Heart Lake Trail Colter / Wolverine Trail An easy 0.5-mile (0.8-km) one-way trail that connects the South Boundary Trail: South Entrance-Harebell to the trails in the USDA Forest Se

images.altText: Two backpackers walk along a trail with a mountain peak in the background.
images.title: Wolverine Creek Trail

bodyText:
This is a remote trailhead at the southern boundary of the park that is not accessible by road. From this trailhead, you can embark on the following trails within the park:

  • Colter / Wolverine Trail
  • South Boundary Trail: South Entrance–Harebell
  • Snake River Canyon Trail
  • Snake River Cutoff Trail
  • Heart Lake Trail

Colter / Wolverine Trail

An easy 0.5-mile (0.8-km) one-way trail that connects the South Boundary Trail: South Entrance–Harebell to the trails in the USDA Forest Service lands south of the park.

South Boundary Trail: South Entrance–Harebell

This moderate 11.6-mile (18.7-km) one-way trail follows the Snake River most of the way, passing by a couple of thermal areas. The fording of the Snake River at the western end of the trail can be dangerous, and even during low-water periods can be waist-deep. This trail travels between the South Entrance in the west at the Harebell Creek Patrol Cabin in the east.

Snake River Canyon Trail

An easy 2.5-mile (4-km) one-way trail that travels between the South Boundary Trail and the Heart River Trail.

Snake River Cutoff Trail

A moderate 3.1-mile (5-km) one-way trail that travels up and over a ridge to connect the South Boundary Trail: South Entrance–Harebell to the Snake River Canyon Trail.

Heart Lake Trail

A moderate 17.4-mile (28-km) one-way trail that leads past thermal areas and to Heart Lake. Heart Lake is about 7.2 miles along the trail from the north end of the trail and 10.2 miles from the junction with the South Boundary Trail. NOTE: Due to bear activity, this trail is closed from April 1 through June 30.

quickFacts.value: Southern park boundary (not accessible by road)
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Comet Geyser
listingDescription: A geyser in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: Water splashes out of a small geyser cone.
images.title: Comet Geyser

bodyText:
Comet Geyser is constantly splashing and doesn't have defined eruptions, just bursts in activity. The cone of geyserite has a unique, almost squished, shape likely due to the continuous splashing. One side of the cone is lower and allows water to flow out into the surrounding area. Orange and yellow thermophiles fill the area of runoff with pea-sized geyserite textures and solidified sinter.

Comet Geyser has an average temperate of 173.3°F (78.5°C), an average pH of 8.5, and an average conductivity of 2300 uS/cm.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Comet Geyser's cone of geyserite has a unique, almost squished, shape likely due to the continuous splashing. One side of the cone is lower and allows water to flow out into the surrounding area. Orange and yellow thermophiles fill the area of runoff with pea-sized geyserite textures and solidified sinter.

title: Commissary Storehouse (1891)
listingDescription: This was the place in Fort Yellowstone where soldiers could purchase goods.

images.altText: Historic buildings with pale siding and red roof shingles.
images.title: Commissary Storehouse

bodyText:
Troops acquired their rations here. Both commissioned and non-commissioned officer’s families were authorized to buy groceries here.

Now, the building is used as a residence for park employees.

  • Explore the Fort Yellowstone Historic District

title: Congress Pool

images.altText: A small, muddy pool with steam rising surrounded by dry mud
images.caption: Muddy pool

bodyText:
Congress Pool was named in 1891 when scientists from around the world converged upon Yellowstone for the Fifth International Geological Congress. Its activity varies from a steaming, dry vent to a boiling murky hot spring to an overflowing blue pool.

It was one of the first pools discovered to contain Sulfolobus, a thermophile that uses sulfur for energy and turns hydrogen sulfide to sulfuric acid in hot acidic water. Newly discovered viruses have been found using Sulfolobus as their host.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Color and Heat Lovers

Hydrothermal features are also habitats in which microscopic organisms survive and thrive. They are called thermophiles: "thermo" for heat and "phile" for lover.

Although they are too small to be seen with the naked eye, trillions are grouped together and appear as masses of color. They are nourished by energy and chemical building blocks.

Colorless and yellow thermophiles grow in the hottest water.

Orange, brown, and green thermophiles grow in cooler waters.

Imagine living in near-boiling temperatures, in hydrothermal features with the alkalinity of baking soda, or in water so acidic that it can burn holes in clothing. Microorganisms in Yellowstone need these extremes to survive.

Norris Geyser Basin

Norris Geyser Basin is one of the hottest and most acidic of Yellowstone’s hydrothermal areas. It is outside of the most recent Yellowstone caldera, but inside the first and largest caldera. It sits on the intersection of three major faults and is a very active earthquake area.

Each year, new hot springs and geysers appear while others become dormant. Geologic events trigger many of these changes. Even small earthquakes can alter hydrothermal behavior. This sudden activity is known as a “thermal disturbance” and can last a few days, or more than a week. Gradually, most features return to “normal.”

No one fully understands why this happens. Norris has the greatest water chemistry diversity among Yellowstone’s hydrothermal areas. The water chemistry changes as the water levels of underground hot water reservoirs fluctuates.

Although Norris is known for its acid features, it also have alkaline hot springs and geysers. As underground water and chemistry shift suddenly, they could contribute to dramatic changes in minerals and pH.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription:
Congress Pool
235 words
There is a paved trail leading to the Geyser Basin Museum. Below the museum, on the way to Congress Pool, the pavement turns to boardwalk, then a dirt trail. The boardwalk resumes near Congress Pool, so named in 1891 for that year's Fifth International Geological Congress. It is but one of many geothermal features located in the Norris Geyser Basin.
With the exception of the boardwalk's first few feet, there are wood railings on both sides. Take care as you step from the trail onto the boardwalk, however, as the transition may be uneven. A small sign affixed to the railing as you stand facing the pool reads simply: "Congress Pool."'
Also standing near the boardwalk is a wayside exhibit entitled "Solfatara: Unstable Ground." Text below the title reads:
"This hillside is venting. As sulfuric acid, gases, and steam escape, they create a barren and very dangerous landscape called a solfatara: scalding mud and steam are often barely covered by hot, crumbling, decomposed rock. Unlike other geothermal features, this solfatara's high concentration of sulfuric acid breaks down the surrounding rock making a confined "plumbing system" unlikely--the gases and steam escape less dramatically."
To the right of the text is a color photograph of a jagged gray mountain. The caption below the picture tells us:
"Sometimes a solfatara has larger, well-defined vents like those at Roaring Mountain (just north of Norris Junction)."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Cooking Hillside

images.altText: Natural area with intermittent bare ground and grass covered hillside and trees in background
images.caption: Landscape view

bodyText:
The trees on this hillside are cooked by steam.

In 1978, an earthquake swarm occurred at Mud Volcano. The intense swarm lasted about seven months. This hillside experienced increased heat, causing the vegetation to die.

Researchers are able to study tree rings to learn about past earthquake swarms and other geological activity that preceded human records, using the records of increased carbon dioxide found in the tree rings.

The Smell

Mudpots are acidic features with a limited water supply. Some microorganisms use hydrogen sulfide, which rises from deep within the earth, as an energy source. They help convert the gas to sulfuric acid, which breaks down rock to wet clay mud and creates the area’s smell. The pungent odor of rotten eggs is caused by the hydrogen sulfide gas.

Various gases escape through the wet clay mud, causing it to bubble. Mudpot consistency and activity vary with the seasons and precipitation.

Mud Volcano Area

The Mud Volcano area has many mudpots and hillsides strewn with trees cooked by steam. The hydrothermal features here are some of the most acidic in the park.

Mud Volcano is near the greatest uplift and sinking of the Yellowstone Caldera floor. Many faults converge here and earthquakes are common.

The areas surrounding the Mud Volcano vent and the other major vent near Old Faithful are called resurgent domes. Resurgent domes are active ground deformation, where the land moves up or down with the fluctuation of the magma chamber below. Scientists monitor these domes closely for information about ongoing volcanic activity.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription:
Cooking Hillside
293 words
You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit featuring a large color photo of a grassy hillside with what appears to be smoldering brush at the crest of the hill. Behind the brush there is a stand of evergreen trees; rolling mountains rise in the distance.
A title at the top left reads: "Cooking Hillside." A subtitle--"Shake, then Bake" is in a box at the panel's bottom left corner. Text below this title tells us:
"Covered by dense forest until 1978, this hillside changed dramatically after a swarm of earthquakes struck the area. In spite of being jolted again and again, the trees remained standing, but met their demise soon afterward when ground temperatures soared to 200 degrees Fahrenheit or 94 degrees Celsius.
"Roots sizzled in the super-heated soil and trees toppled over one by one as steam rose eerily between the branches. No wonder the hill was dubbed â€˜Cooking Hillside.'"
To the right of the large photo are two smaller photos placed one above the other. The title "Vanishing Pines" is above the top photo, which shows an aerial view of trees covering the hillside. A large oval area on the left side of the photo is outlined with a dotted white line; the words "You are Here" appear in red accompanied by a black arrow pointing toward the middle right side of the indicated area. A caption reads:
"As seen in this aerial photograph, thick woodlands grew here before 1978."
The bottom photo shows a similar aerial view of the area but with less trees. The caption below this photo tells us:
"In 1978 and 1979, numerous trees died in the smoldering ground, leaving behind their fallen trunks as a reminder of their once stately presence."
END OF MESSAGE

title: Coral Geyser
listingDescription: Coral Geyser is a hydrothermal feature at Biscuit Basin.
bodyText:
Coral Geyser is a small clear pool sitting low in a cavern-like opening. Soft and fractured sinter covers the surface area, as does some moss vegetation. Coral Geyser has minimal history of eruptions, mostly after the 1959 earthquake, but since 2004 has had steady splashing activity.

Coral Geyser has an average temperate of 187.5°F (86.4°C), an average pH of 8.4, and an average conductivity of 2000 uS/cm.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Coral Geyser is a small clear pool sitting low in a cavern-like opening. Soft and fractured sinter covers the surface area, as does some moss vegetation.

title: Coyote Creek Trailhead (2N1)
listingDescription:
This is a remote trailhead at the northern boundary of the park that is not accessible by road. From this trailhead, you can embark on the following trail within the park:
- Coyote Creek Trail

images.altText: A person hikes through a meadow in between two forested hillsides.
images.title: Coyote Creek Trail

bodyText:
This is a remote trailhead at the northern boundary of the park that is not accessible by road. From this trailhead, you can embark on the following trail within the park:

  • Coyote Creek Trail

title: Crested Pool
listingDescription: A hydrothermal pool in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: A deep blue hot spring surrounded by orange microbial mats.
images.title: Crested Pool

bodyText:
With temperatures that average temperate of 191.1°F (88.4°C), Crested Pool is almost constantly boiling, sometimes to 6 feet (2 m) or more.

The extreme heat prevents most bacterial growth, resulting in exceptionally clear blue water. Boiling is particularly active along the intricate sinter formation circling the spring, the “crested” edge. Listen for the sizzling.

Crested Pool has an average pH of 8.9 and an average conductivity of 2269 uS/cm.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Crested Pool 298 words You are now facing Crested Pool, a hot spring named for the whitish-gray mineral deposits that surrounds its dark-blue pool. A wayside overlooking the pool is entitled “Crested Pool: Superheated Waters” and features a large color drawing of the pool’s underground structure--narrow at the bottom with a wide mouth. Text below the title reads: “Hot springs are the most numerous type of thermal feature in Yellowstone. More than 10,000 are scattered across Yellowstone's 2 million acres, but few are as hot and as intensely colored as Crested Pool. Water temperatures within the pool often exceed the boiling point (199 degrees Fahrenheit or 93 degrees Celsius at this elevation) and reach superheated temperatures of 201 to 202 degrees Fahrenheit (94 degrees Celsius). The spring's intense blue color results when sunlight passes into its clear waters. Blue, from the rainbow of colors in visible light, is scattered the most and, therefore, is the color we see.” Labels on the drawing include the white sinter crest surrounding the pool both above ground and below; a triangular ray of sunlight with all seven colors of the rainbow that strikes the pool’s surface; short arrows representing the cooler water moving downward into the pool; and longer arrows indicating superheated water rising from the pool’s center. There are also three short blue arrows pointing into the sky from the point where the sunlight hits the pool. More text to the right of the drawing tells us: “At times, fierce, boiling waters within Crested Pool can explode to heights of 7 feet, acting like a geyser. It is believed, however, that no constrictions block the flow of water to the surface. The spring's wide mouth and 43-foot depth provide a natural conduit for superheated water to circulate continuously to the surface.” END OF MESSAGE

title: Crystal Spring
listingDescription: A hydrothermal pool in the Upper Geyser Basin
bodyText:
Crystal Spring is a small pool, with almost colorless water. The pool is shallow on one side, but drops into the vent on the other side. Solidified sinter deposits line the edge of the pool, with some areas appearing to be outflow channels when water level is high enough. Some orange thermophiles exist further down the outwash channel.

Crystal Spring has an average temperate of 189.4°F (87.5°C), an average pH of 9.2, and an average conductivity of 2058 uS/cm.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Crystal Spring is a small pool, with almost colorless water. The pool is shallow on one side, but drops into the vent on the other side. Solidified sinter deposits line the edge of the pool, with some areas appearing to be outflow channels when water level is high enough. Some orange thermophiles exist further down the outwash channel.

title: Cygnet Lakes Trailhead (4N3)
listingDescription: This trailhead in the middle of the park provides access to the following trail:- Cygnet Lakes TrailThere is parking at the trailhead. Cygnet Lakes Trail This 8.2-mile (13.2-km) there-and-back trail is relatively flat and exposed. The trail leads to a series of lakes where waterfowl may be seen. Backcountry RegulationsPermit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at the Center Backcountry Office: (307) 344-2160. Hiking Hike in groups of

images.altText: A burned area with down trees, new growth, and mountains in the distance.
images.title: Cygnet Lakes Trail

bodyText:
This trailhead in the middle of the park provides access to the following trail:

  • Cygnet Lakes Trail

There is parking at the trailhead.

Cygnet Lakes Trail

This 8.2-mile (13.2-km) there-and-back trail is relatively flat and exposed. The trail leads to a series of lakes where waterfowl may be seen.

Backcountry Regulations

Permit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at the Center Backcountry Office: (307) 344-2160.

Hiking

Hike in groups of 3 or more; keep your group together. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to return. Know your route, carry a map, and be able to navigate. Do not hike after dark. Stay on established trails; off-trail travel prohibited in thermal areas.

Fishing and Boating

Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS) inspection required for all watercraft including boats, float tubes, and stand up paddle boards. Felt soles prohibited.

Riding and Packing

Proof of negative Coggins test within last 12 months required.

Food Storage and Camping

These regulations apply to ALL backcountry users. Sleep 100 yards (91 m) from your food storage and cooking areas. Do not leave food, trash, toiletries, backpacks, coolers, water bottles, or any potential attractant unattended. Store food in an approved bear resistant container or hang on a food pole 10 feet (3 m) above the ground and 4 feet (1 m) from sides. Carry a minimum of 35 feet (11 m) of rope. Campfires allowed only in designated campsites within established fire rings. Extinguish campfires completely before leaving site.

Follow LEAVE NO TRACE travel and camping techniques. Enjoy the backcountry and help keep it clean for others to enjoy. Bury human waste and toilet tissue in a 6–8 inch (15–18 cm) deep “cat hole” at least 100 feet (30 m) from water and trails.

River Crossings

Park waters are swift and cold. Swimming in park rivers is not recommended. River crossings are hazardous.

Lightning Safety

During thunderstorms, descend to lower elevation, avoid open areas and isolated tall trees. Assume lightning position: feet together, crouch on foam pad or sit on pack, hands over ears.

Regulations

 

  • Leave What You Find: Do not collect anything from the park.
  • No Pets: No pets on trail. Obtain service animal regulations at backcountry offices.
  • No Hunting: No hunting or discharge of firearms.
  • No Motorized Vehicles: No motorized vehicles on trails.
  • Wheeled Vehicles Restricted: No bicycles, strollers, or wheeled vehicles (except wheelchairs), except where specified.

In an emergency, dial 9-1-1 or contact the nearest ranger station.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

Be Prepared for a Bear Encounter

Grizzly and black bears inhabit all of Yellowstone National Park.

Be Alert: Watch for signs of bear activity: scratches in trees, tracks, scat, or dig sites. Avoid dead animals.

Make Noise: Avoid surprising a bear by calling out and clapping your hands at regular intervals to make your presence known.

Carry Bear Spray: Carry bear spray and know how to use it. Keep it immediately available, not inside your pack.

Hike in Groups: Travel in groups of 3 or more is recommended. Stay with your group at all times.

What to do...

If You Encounter a Bear: Stay calm, do not run. Quietly detour or back away; stop if this seems to agitate the bear. Stay at least 100 yards (91 m) from bears. Do NOT feed bears or other animals.

If a Bear Charges You: Stand still, do not run. Stand your ground and use your bear spray. Spray when the bear is 60 feet (18 m) away or closer. If a bear charges, it may be a bluff charge.

If a Bear Makes Contact: Drop to the ground; play dead. Lie face down and clasp your hands over the back of your neck; stay still and silent. Wait several minutes after the bear leaves before getting up and leaving the area.

This trail crosses open meadows and provides views of the surrounding Gallatin Range. Backcountry RegulationsPermit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at

images.altText: A pair of hikers finishing their hike by passing the trailhead information sign.

bodyText:
This trailhead along Highway 191 in the western part of the park provides access to one trail:

  • Dailey Creek Trail

Dailey Creek Trail

title: Daisy Geyser
listingDescription: A geyser in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: Steam and water erupt from a small geyser
images.caption: Erupting steam

bodyText:
The view of this geyser is also a good view of the Upper Geyser Basin. Daisy Geyser erupts at an angle to a height of 75 feet (23 m) for 3-5 minutes. Daisy Geyser is usually predictable, with eruption intervals of 120-210 minutes. The exception is when the nearby and unpredictable Splendid Geyser erupts.

##View all geyser predictions

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Daisy Geyser 375 words Daisy Geyser is one of several water features located in Yellowstone’s Upper Geyser Basin. As you approach the geyser, please take care as the wood boardwalk running alongside the site does not have handrails. Standing to one side of the boardwalk is a wayside exhibit entitled “Daisy Geyer.” Text below the title reads: “Daisy Geyser is part of an interconnected group of geysers and hot springs. Underground cracks and fissures allow water and heat to circulate between the various features in this group. When the activity of one feature affects the behavior of another, it is called an exchange of function. Daisy Geyser is usually quite predictable, but when nearby Bonita Pool overflows excessively or when Splendid Geyser erupts, Daisy Geyser can become irregular.” Below this text--and superimposed over a black-and-white aerial photograph of the region--is a map indicating the location of Daisy Geyser between Brilliant Pool, Splendid Geyser, and Comet Geyser to the west and Bank Geyser, Radiator Geyser, and Bonita Pool to the east. A small black arrow labeled “You Are Here” points to your position on the boardwalk that runs from east to west below these sites; Daisy Geyser is located several yards straight in front of you. Below and to the left of the map are two “Fast Facts” highlighted with bullet points: “Daisy Geyser erupts to heights of 75 feet or more. “On average, the duration of Daisy Geyser's eruptions are 3 to 5 minutes.” Filling the left half of the panel is a color photograph of a wide pool from which a tower of water shoots at a slight angle several feet into a deep blue sky. A caption under the photo tells us: “An eruption of Daisy Geyser starts with boiling water splashing from one of several vents in the thick sinter ledge partially surrounding the geyser's crater. This eruption indicator means that a full eruption is about to occur. Boiling water soon pours over the crater's edge, and the splashing increases. Suddenly, bursts of water angle into the sky, reaching heights of 75 feet and lasting from 3 to 5 minutes.” A notation in the panel’s bottom right corner reads: “This exhibit made possible by a generous grant from the Yellowstone Association.” END OF MESSAGE

title: DeLacy Creek Picnic Area

images.altText: Couple picnicking in wooded area
images.title: DeLacy Creek Picnic Area
images.caption: Picnicking on Craig Pass

bodyText:
This picnic area has 10 picnic tables and 1 vault toilet.

Picnicking Notes

Campfires are allowed only in picnic areas with fire grates. Camp stoves (liquid or gas) and self-contained charcoal grills may be used for food preparation at all locations. Do not feed any wild animals, including birds. It is unhealthy and encourages aggressive behavior that may require management action. All food, trash, coolers, and cooking tools must be kept secure in a bear-proof container unless in immediate use. Overnight camping is not allowed in any picnic area.

Be Alert for Bears

  • Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
  • Hike in groups of three or more people.
  • Make noise in areas with limited visibility.
  • Do not run! Back away slowly.

title: DeLacy Creek Trailhead (7K2)
listingDescription: This trailhead provides access to the following trail:- DeLacy Creek Trail DeLacy Creek Trail A 5.8-mile (9.3-km) there-and-back trail that travels along a forest's edge and through open meadows to the shores of Yellowstone's largest backcountry lake. Look for sandhill cranes, moose, and water birds. Backcountry RegulationsPermit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at the Center Backcountry Office: (307) 344-2160. Hiking Hike in grou

images.altText: A wooden sign marks the start of a bare ground trail that heads into the forest across a road.
images.caption: Trailhead across the road

bodyText:
This trailhead provides access to the following trail:

  • DeLacy Creek Trail

DeLacy Creek Trail

title: Depression Geyser
listingDescription: A geyser in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: A small, blue pool sits in a small, gray ground depression.
images.caption: Depression Geyser from the boardwalk

bodyText:
The 1959 Hebgen Lake Earthquake seems to have caused this geyser to become more active. Depression Geyser erupts water 6–10 feet (1.8–3 m) every 8–36 hours. Depression Geyser is a deep blue pool with two main vent openings and a connected smaller pool to the north-northwest. However, it has become less active and more varied in its eruptions since an earthquake in 1983. Eruptions occur every 8–36 hours.

Depression Geyser has an average temperate of 179.2°F (81.8°C), an average pH of 8.6, and an average conductivity of 1854 uS/cm.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.

title: Divide Trailhead
listingDescription: This trailhead provides access to the following trails:- Spring Creek Trail- Divide Trail Spring Creek Trail An easy 8-mile (12.9-km) there-and-back trail that follows a small creek along an old stagecoach route. This is a popular ski trail during the winter season. Divide Trail A moderate 3.4-mile (5.5-km) there-and-back trail that leads to the location where there was once a fire lookout. Backcountry RegulationsPermit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight cam

images.altText: A trail drops down from a paved parking area and enters a conifer forest.
images.caption: Trailhead

bodyText:
This trailhead provides access to the following trails:

  • Spring Creek Trail
  • Divide Trail

Spring Creek Trail

An easy 8-mile (12.9-km) there-and-back trail that follows a small creek along an old stagecoach route. This is a popular ski trail during the winter season.

Divide Trail

A moderate 3.4-mile (5.5-km) there-and-back trail that leads to the location where there was once a fire lookout.

Backcountry Regulations

Permit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at the Center Backcountry Office: (307) 344-2160.

Hiking

Hike in groups of 3 or more; keep your group together. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to return. Know your route, carry a map, and be able to navigate. Do not hike after dark. Stay on established trails; off-trail travel prohibited in thermal areas.

Fishing and Boating

Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS) inspection required for all watercraft including boats, float tubes, and stand up paddle boards. Felt soles prohibited.

Riding and Packing

Proof of negative Coggins test within last 12 months required.

Food Storage and Camping

These regulations apply to ALL backcountry users. Sleep 100 yards (91 m) from your food storage and cooking areas. Do not leave food, trash, toiletries, backpacks, coolers, water bottles, or any potential attractant unattended. Store food in an approved bear resistant container or hang on a food pole 10 feet (3 m) above the ground and 4 feet (1 m) from sides. Carry a minimum of 35 feet (11 m) of rope. Campfires allowed only in designated campsites within established fire rings. Extinguish campfires completely before leaving site.

Follow LEAVE NO TRACE travel and camping techniques. Enjoy the backcountry and help keep it clean for others to enjoy. Bury human waste and toilet tissue in a 6–8 inch (15–18 cm) deep “cat hole” at least 100 feet (30 m) from water and trails.

River Crossings

Park waters are swift and cold. Swimming in park rivers is not recommended. River crossings are hazardous.

Lightning Safety

During thunderstorms, descend to lower elevation, avoid open areas and isolated tall trees. Assume lightning position: feet together, crouch on foam pad or sit on pack, hands over ears.

Regulations

 

  • Leave What You Find: Do not collect anything from the park.
  • No Pets: No pets on trail. Obtain service animal regulations at backcountry offices.
  • No Hunting: No hunting or discharge of firearms.
  • No Motorized Vehicles: No motorized vehicles on trails.
  • Wheeled Vehicles Restricted: No bicycles, strollers, or wheeled vehicles (except wheelchairs), except where specified.

In an emergency, dial 9-1-1 or contact the nearest ranger station.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

Be Prepared for a Bear Encounter

Grizzly and black bears inhabit all of Yellowstone National Park.

Be Alert: Watch for signs of bear activity: scratches in trees, tracks, scat, or dig sites. Avoid dead animals.

Make Noise: Avoid surprising a bear by calling out and clapping your hands at regular intervals to make your presence known.

Carry Bear Spray: Carry bear spray and know how to use it. Keep it immediately available, not inside your pack.

Hike in Groups: Travel in groups of 3 or more is recommended. Stay with your group at all times.

What to do...

If You Encounter a Bear: Stay calm, do not run. Quietly detour or back away; stop if this seems to agitate the bear. Stay at least 100 yards (91 m) from bears. Do NOT feed bears or other animals.

If a Bear Charges You: Stand still, do not run. Stand your ground and use your bear spray. Spray when the bear is 60 feet (18 m) away or closer. If a bear charges, it may be a bluff charge.

If a Bear Makes Contact: Drop to the ground; play dead. Lie face down and clasp your hands over the back of your neck; stay still and silent. Wait several minutes after the bear leaves before getting up and leaving the area.

title: Double Cavalry Barracks (1909)
listingDescription: The largest building constructed by Scottish stonemasons in Fort Yellowstone, it is now the headquarters for Yellowstone National Park.

images.altText: Large, three-story stone building with porches on each story and red tile roof.
images.caption: Modern-day view of the historic Double Cavalry Barracks.

bodyText:
The Double Cavalry Barracks housed two cavalry troops (200 men). It is the largest building in Fort Yellowstone.

The Army protected the park and ensured access, but they could not fully satisfy the visitors' desire to learn about the park. Further, each of the 14 other national parks established in the late 1800s and early 1900s was separately administered, resulting in uneven management, inefficiency, and lack of direction.

Setting the Stage

The management of Yellowstone by the Army helped set the stage for the creation of an agency whose sole purpose was to manage the national parks. Promoters of this idea gathered support from influential journalists, railroads likely to profit from increased park tourism, and members of Congress.

In 1916 when Congress created the National Park Service, the Army turned Fort Yellowstone over to the new agency. Local resistance made this transition difficult, and the Army returned in 1917. The park was fully under National Park Service control in 1918, and the Army departed.

Fort Yellowstone is reminder of the role veterans of the US Army served in protecting and preserving Yellowstone National Park for future generations.

  • Explore the Fort Yellowstone Historic District
audioDescription: Double Cavalry Barracks 382 words A wayside exhibit is situated at the corner of a three story stone building with wide railed, wooden porch on the second and third floors. At ground level, stone columns support the porch, flanked by wings with five windows. On the same wings, three windows are on the second and third levels. The wayside exhibit is titled “From Soldier to Ranger.” “The National Park Service Act was signed on August 25, 1916. About one month later on September 30th, twenty-three soldiers were discharged from the army to be hired by the civilian agency as the first rangers in Yellowstone. Included with the soldiers were some of the old-time civilian scouts who had led the soldiers in patrolling the backcountry for poachers. These first rangers, like modern rangers, took pride in the ability to "do it all" including fighting wildfires, investigating accidents, controlling traffic, providing park visitors with information and patrolling the backcountry.” A large black-and-white photo shows four rows of 11 to 16 dark-uniformed men either standing or sitting in front of the building in front of the porch. Included among them are two men dressed all in white with white caps. One soldier holds a pole flying a small white flag adorned with a dark letter “F.” A caption below the photo reads: “The Army's legacy is visible in wood and stone, and in the very survival of Yellowstone as one of the world's great symbols of the National Park idea.” The first of two smaller black-and-white photos in the panel’s top right corner shows a bearded man wearing a wide-brimmed hat pinned at two points to the crown. Beneath the outer coat is another layer with a popped collar. The caption tells us: “Harry Yount was gamekeeper in Yellowstone from 1880 to 1881 and is considered the first ranger.” The second photo depicts a woman wearing a dark ranger uniform with jodphur pants. Her hand rests on the wheel of a stagecoach that reaches nearly as tall as her head. A ranger hat is in her other hand and a badge hangs from her breast pocket. She has a short haircut. The caption reads: “Ranger Herma Albertson, circa 1925.” A notation in the exhibit’s bottom left corner reads: “This exhibit made possible by a generous grant from The Yellowstone Association.” END OF MESSAGE

title: Doublet Pool
listingDescription: A hydrothermal feature in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: Close-up of the white rim around both pools, as well as the deep vents far below the surface.
images.caption: Close-up view of Doublet Pool.

bodyText:
Doublet Pool is actually two clear pools connected in the middle, allowing water to flow between. Deep vents exist in the center of the pools with shallow shelves at the edges of the pools. Raised, sawtooth-textured sinter outlines the edge of the pools and lines areas of the outwash channel. Some water spills out of the sawtooth textures around the pools, resulting in starburst-like trails of orange thermophiles, as well as the saw colors lining the outwash channel. Only rarely has Doublet Pool actually erupted, once after the 1959 earthquake, but most of its activity is bubbling and steaming.

Doublet Pool has an average temperate of 187.8°F (86.5°C), an average pH of 8.9, and an average conductivity of 1992 uS/cm.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
