title: Lake Village Post Office

images.altText: Peeling paint on a wood-paneled building with large windows, a US flag, and lettering "US Post Office"
images.caption: Post office

bodyText:
This is where you can mail letters and packages, or buy postage. This location is only open during the summer season.

2023 Season

  • Open May 8–September 29, 8:30 am–5:00 pm
  • Opening and closing dates are subject to change based on future conditions and public health guidance.

Accessibility

Wheelchair-accessible. Designated accessible parking.

title: Lakeshore Geyser

images.altText: A geyser cone sticks just above the water of a large lake.
images.caption: Cone of Lakeshore Geyser

bodyText:
Aptly named, the vents of Lakeshore Geyser are often underwater in the spring and summer, when the water level of Yellowstone Lake is higher due to snowmelt.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.

title: Lamar Buffalo Ranch: Birthplace of Wildlife Conservation
listingDescription: The Lamar Buffalo Ranch occupies a significant place in the history of American wildlife conservation and management. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982.

images.altText: A rustic wooden fence and corral with the sign Lamar Buffalo Ranch next to wooden buildings.

bodyText:
The Lamar Buffalo Ranch occupies a significant place in the history of American wildlife conservation and management. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982.

History

The extermination of bison throughout the west in the 1800s nearly eliminated them from Yellowstone. Even after the park was established in 1872, poachers faced few deterrents. With only 25 bison counted in the park in 1901, Congress appropriated $15,000 to augment the herd by purchasing 21 bison from private owners. As part of the first effort to preserve a wild species through intensive management, these bison were fed and bred in Lamar Valley at what became known as the Lamar Buffalo Ranch.

As the herd grew in size, bison were released to breed with the park’s free-roaming population. Bison from the ranch were also used to start and supplement herds on other public and tribal land. Today the Yellowstone bison population numbers in the thousands. It’s one the largest populations in North America and among the few that is genetically pure because it has not been interbred with cattle.

A program to raise bison like domestic cattle in Yellowstone may seem incongruous and unnecessary in retrospect, but the buffalo ranch stands as a reminder that today’s well-intended wildlife management policies may have unintended consequences and be overturned by changing values and advances in ecological knowledge.

As listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the Lamar Buffalo Ranch Historic District includes five buildings: a ranger station, constructed in 1915 as the buffalo keeper’s residence; a pole fenced corral built and rebuilt from 1915 to the 1930s; a log barn for hay and horses (1927); a bunkhouse (1929); and a residence used for the assistant buffalo keeper that was moved to the ranch in 1938 from Soda Butte (where it had probably been a ranger station). The vegetation around the ranch is mostly sagebrush and nonnative grasses that were planted during the period of hay cultivation. Remnants of irrigation ditches, fencing, and water troughs remain throughout the ranch.

Education & Sustainability

Today Expedition Yellowstone and Yellowstone Forever Institute use the Lamar Buffalo Ranch as a base camp for educational field classes and seminars. In keeping with its rustic character, the Lamar Buffalo Ranch remains off-the-grid. Thanks to partnerships with Yellowstone Forever, Sharp, and Toyota, a 44 kw photovoltaic array provides power to the ranch. The solar panels are tucked out of site so as not to affect Lamar Valley’s panoramic views. As a pilot project, Toyota provided 208 used hybrid car batteries to store power on site. It's hoped this technology will provide a new alternative for delivering power to remote locations throughout the world.

These partnerships enable the National Park Service to use the buffalo ranch as a model for environmental stewardship. Future plans call improving the energy efficiency of the historic buildings with things like low-flow water fixtures, on-demand hot water, and more energy-efficient windows (all while preserving the integrity of the original structures). Eventually, we hope to remove all propane appliances so the ranch can operate entirely free of fossil fuels.

The Future of Bison Management

The protection and recovery of bison in Yellowstone is one of the great triumphs of American conservation. Efforts centered at the Lamar Buffalo Ranch succeeded in bringing this species back from the brink of extinction. Today we face the challenge of maintaining a wild, migratory population of bison in a modern landscape. Read more about the success and controversy surrounding these efforts.

quickFacts.value: The center of efforts to conserve wild bison in America
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Lamar River Bridge

images.altText: A low exhibit behind a log barrier on a overlook of a river bordered by trees with a mountain in the background
images.caption: Exhibit and river

bodyText:
At first, travel to and within the park was difficult. Visitors had to transport themselves or pay a costly transportation company.

In the park, there were only a few places for food and lodging. Access improved in 1883 when the Northern Pacific Railroad reached Cinnabar, Montana, a town near the North Entrance.

Wagons to Automobiles

After checking into the hotel, they toured the hot springs. For the next four days, they bounced along in passenger coaches called “Yellowstone wagons,” which had to be unloaded at steep grades. Each night visitors enjoyed a warm bed and a lavish meal at a grand hotel.

These visitors carried home unforgettable memories of experiences and sights, and they wrote hundreds of accounts of their trips. They recommended the tour to their friends, and each year more came to Yellowstone to see its wonders.

When the first automobile entered in 1915, Yellowstone truly became a national park, accessible to anyone who could afford a car.

Expect Travel Hazards and Delays

  • Drive cautiously and defensively.
  • Allow time for road congestion.
  • Do not stop on or block a road.
  • Use pullouts; stay in your car to watch animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar River Bridge
301 words
You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit located alongside a road at one end of a paved two-lane bridge. The wayside is entitled "Not for the Faint of Heart" and features a large black-and-white photo of a timber bridge spanning a narrow river. The railings on either side of the bridge and the pillars, or piers, supporting it from below are also constructed from wood timbers. A caption below the photo reads: "First Lamar River Bridge 1897 to 1918." Text below the title tells us:
"Before paved roads and sturdy bridges were constructed, a journey through the park was filled with thrills and frustrations. Imagine traveling in a bouncing, swaying stagecoach or hand-cranked auto over narrow dirt roads with blind curves, steep drop-offs and no bridges. When it rained, you would have been stuck up to the axle in deep ruts on slick, muddy roads. And when it was dry, you would have choked on dust that clogged eyes and nose and coated you from head to toe."

A smaller black-and-white photo located in the panel's bottom left corner shows a bridge with square stone support piers and metal railings, perhaps of iron or steel. A caption identifies this as "Second Lamar River Bridge 1920 to 1939."

A small color photo in the panel's bottom right corner depicts the concrete bridge as "Third Lamar River Bridge 1940 to 2012."

Above this photo are two more small black-and-white photos. The top photo, captioned "Stagecoach fording the Lamar River," shows four horses pulling a covered stagecoach through water as high as their bellies. The next photo shows an early 20th-century vehicle tilted slightly to one side at the end of a muddy road marked with numerous deep ruts. The caption reads "Stuck in the mud in Lamar Valley."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lamar Valley - Evidence of Glaciers

images.altText: Several cow elk graze on a hill covered with sagebrush next to snow-dusted boulders
images.caption: Elk among glacial drift

bodyText:
Glaciers result when, for a period of years, more snow falls in an area than melts.

Once the snow reaches a certain depth, it turns into ice and begins to move under the force of gravity or the pressure of its own weight.

During this movement, rocks are picked up and carried in the ice, and these rocks grind Earth’s surface.

Ice and water erode and transport earth materials as well as rocks and sediments.

Glaciers also deposit materials. Large U-shaped valleys, ridges of debris (moraines), and out-of place boulders (erratics) are evidence of a glacier’s passing.

A glacial deposit near Tower Fall in Yellowstone dates back 1.3 million years.

The Earliest People in Yellowstone

People were probably not here when the entire area was covered by ice caps and glaciers. The last period of ice coverage ended 13,000-14,000 years ago. Sometime after that and before 11,000 years ago, humans arrived in Yellowstone.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar Valley - Evidence of Glaciers
335 words

There are 2 sections in this description.

Section 1 (125 words)

You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit located beside two evergreen trees overlooking a wide pond, low hills, and distant mountains.. The wayside is entitled "Phantom Glaciers." Text below the title tells us:

"After carving the mountains and valleys that you see from here, a once powerful glacier melted and retreated, leaving clues of its existence-scattered ponds, ground moraines, and isolated boulders.

"Born during the glacier's retreat, this kettle pond is now home to many plants and animals. Ground moraines are also present-the low hills located beyond the kettle pond.

"Watch for similar signs of former glaciers as you travel through northern Yellowstone. As geologists tell time, the last glacier retreated from here very recently. By 12,000 years ago, it had completely vanished."

Section 2 (190 words)

In the panel's top right corner is a color photo depicting low brown hills rising beyond a green valley. A black line pointing to the hills is labeled "Ground Moraines." More text reads:

"As the glacier melted, piles of rock and soil dropped and settled, forming these low hills, or ground moraines."

Spanning the bottom third of the panel is a sepia-toned drawing of a vast landscape similar to that shown in the photo. A black line pointing to a wide but narrow pond in the center of the drawing is labeled "Kettle Ponds." Text below the label reads:

"As a glacier recedes, house-sized blocks of ice are sometimes left behind, partially buried in ground-up rock and soil. Although insulated by glacial silt, the ice gradually melts, leaving a steep-sided or kettle-shaped depression that can later fill with water and form a pond."

A black line pointing to one of several round-topped boulders dotting the area in front of the pond is labeled "Glacial Erratics." More text tells us:

"Far from their origins, these giant boulders were carried by ice for many miles before being abandoned by the melting glacier."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lamar Valley - Predators and Prey

images.altText: A wolf chases magpies and ravens from an elk carcass
images.caption: Wolf, magpies, and ravens at elk carcass, Lamar Valley

bodyText:
Wolves eat a wide variety of prey, large and small. They efficiently hunt large prey that other predators cannot usually kill.

In Yellowstone, 90% of their winter prey is elk. In the summer, 10 to 15% of their summer prey is deer. They also can kill bison.

Many other animals benefit from wolf kills. For example, when wolves kill an elk, ravens arrive almost immediately. Coyotes arrive soon after, waiting nearby until the wolves are satisfied.

Bears will attempt to chase the wolves away, and are usually successful. Many other animals consume the remains, from magpies to invertebrates.

The northern range of Yellowstone is one of the best places in the world to watch wolves.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar Valley - Predators and Prey
640 words
There are 3 sections in this description.
Section 1 (276 words)
You are facing the first of two wayside exhibits standing in front of a low timber fence overlooking Lamar Valley. This wayside is entitled "Food for the Masses." Featured on the panel is a large painting depicting two wolves and three birds of different sizes gathering around a downed elk. A tall bear watches from afar. Text below the title reads:

"Share and share alike? Not exactly...though hard won and not easily surrendered, a wolf-kill provides food for numerous species. Some arrive almost as the prey falls. Others are content to wait their turn rather than risk confrontation. The wolves simply eat as much as they can as fast as they can while a community of scavengers assembles.

"The leftovers are well used. Nutrients leach into the soil, increasing the fertility of this grassy valley. Even antlers are gradually consumed by rodents who gnaw on the calcium-rich bone."

Four dark insects-two with wings and two without- are pictured in the painting's upper right corner. More text tells us:

"The arrival of invertebrates transforms the wolf-kill into its own ecosystem. Some insects consume the remains, while others feast on the fly eggs and larvae that have colonized the carcass."

Painted in the panel's bottom right corner are a "common raven (Corvus corax)" and a
"grizzly bear (Ursus arctos)." Text below the raven reads:

"Smarter than your average bird! Ravens follow wolf packs knowing that this will eventually provide a meal. Dozens arrive at a wolf-kill within minutes."

Text below the grizzly bear tells us:

"Wolves and grizzlies frequently collide at wolf-kills. Unwilling to pass up an easy meal, grizzlies have little trouble taking over the carcass."

Section 2 (170 words)
The second wayside is entitled "A Range of Complexities." A painting in the panel's center depicts two large brown bison and one small calf standing in low prairie grass. Text in the panel's top left corner tells us:

"The only constant is change. Sometimes called â€˜America's Serengeti,' Yellowstone's northern range has been at the heart of decades of discussion about resource preservation. Early management focused on artificially altering the landscape. Predators were removed to facilitate larger herds of hooved animals. Herd sizes grew quickly as a result. Believing the range was overgrazed, the National Park Service acted the part of predator by reducing the size of those herds. Live animals were trapped and shipped to reserves across North America. Thousands were killed in the park to limit population size and reduce disease. Public outcry halted these control actions in the 1960s.

"The policy of natural regulation was then adopted. Predation, winter mortality, and other ecological processes-along with science-based management when needed-
would now regulate wildlife populations within park boundaries."

Section 3 (172 words)

To the right of this text is a map painting showing "Yellowstone National Park" in yellow and "Yellowstone's northern range" in green.

Painted in the panel's bottom left corner is a single elk with large antlers. Painted to the right is a group of various grazing animals. More text reads:

"Spreading the Wealth. Once thought to be damaging grasslands on the northern range, hooved animals actually enhance grassy vegetation growth. As ungulate herds drift across the range, their hooves stimulate the soil, and their waste quickly cycles nutrients back into the ecosystem."

Painted in the panel's bottom right corner are a "North American Pronghorn (Antilocapra americana)" and a "Coyote (Canis latrans)." Text below the pronghorn tells us:

"Pronghorn are the fastest land mammal in North America. Their oversized windpipe, heart and lungs allow them to sustain sprints of up to 50 miles per hour."

Text below the coyote reads:

"Coyote have adapted to numerous changes in the past and always find a way to thrive. They are one of Yellowstone's great adapters!"

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lamar Valley - Trophic Cascades

images.altText: Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves. Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.
images.caption: Keep distance from animals

bodyText:
The reintroduction of wolves created the chance to observe how a top predator influences its plant-eating prey and how changes in those prey influence plants.

By reducing the abundance of herbivores or changing their feeding behavior, predators free plants from being eaten. This series of effects is called a “trophic cascade.”

It is too soon to know for sure if this trophic cascade is actually happening, and how extensive it might be—or if it is just one of many factors at work. Ongoing, long-term scientific research will continue to examine the complex fabric of the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem.

Effects of Wolves

Accumulated studies show that the loss of wolves from the food web on the northern range in the 1930s led to a loss of willows and other woody plants by allowing excessive grazing by elk.

Most researchers agree that reintroduced wolves have caused elk to change their behavior and many studies have shown a correlation between the presence of wolves and increased growth in willows. However, not all scientists agree that this relationship is causal.

For example, some researchers say elk don’t linger in willow or aspen areas where visibility is poor and that this behavioral change prevents them from eating as much willow or aspen. Other scientists argue that fluctuations in the availability of groundwater explain the growth patterns in woody vegetation.

Ecologists have documented a substantial rise in temperature in the northern range: from 1995 to 2005, the number of days above freezing increased from 90 to 110. Changes in precipitation and effects of global climate change are also affecting vegetation growth.

Wildlife Watching

The northern range of Yellowstone is one of the best places in the world to watch wolves.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar Valley - Trophic Cascades
306 words

You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit entitled "The Wolf Effect." Featured on this panel is a large color painting depicting a lush landscape of green vegetation and both short and tall yellow-leaved aspen trees growing alongside a river, or creek. Text below the title reads:

"The reintroduction of wolves brought change to an ecosystem that evolved without them for almost 70 years. Although wolves do not directly affect all life around them, their effects possibly tumble down the entire food chain. This hypothesis is called a trophic cascade.

"As predators disappeared from the landscape decades ago, the park's elk population swelled. Unnaturally large herds were more likely to suffer from poor nutrition, and included many old, weak animals. Wolves and other restored predators preyed on the most vulnerable animals and quickly became a factor in creating smaller, stronger herds.

"Elk now linger far less along streams where they once browsed heavily. Willows, aspens, and cottonwoods are growing taller, providing habitat for a multitude of species at streamside areas."

More text in the panel's bottom left corner tells us:

"Taller willows allow for greater diversity of bird species. Birds nest and forage at different heights, making it possible for many species to coexist."

Additional text near a beaver dam spanning the water in the painting's center reads:

"Beaver recolonizing the northern range feed almost exclusively on willow. They create ponds and channels, providing valuable habitat for waterfowl, amphibians, reptiles, and fish."


Text on the panel's right side reads:

"Taller vegetation shades the water, cooling it. Fish are attracted to the cooler water, while lush branches attract more insects for fish to feed on."

Several labels throughout the scene identify various birds-"Yellow Warbler," "Willow Flycatcher," "Wilson's Warbler," and "Cinnamon teal" ducks-as well as "Beaver," "Elk," "Young aspen" and "Cutthroat trout."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lamar Valley - Wildlife Watching

images.altText: Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves. Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.
images.caption: Keep distance from animals

bodyText:
Elk, bison, deer, and pronghorn thrive in the grasslands of this area, known as the northern range. In fact, some of the largest wild herds of bison and elk in North America are found here.

The northern range is critical winter habitat for these large animals, which in turn provide food for several packs of wolves. Coyotes are also common, and occasional bobcat, cougar, or red fox are reported.

Leave antlers, wildflowers, rocks, and arrowheads where you find them.

Wild Yellowstone

The reintroduction of the wolf to Yellowstone restored an important element of ecological completeness in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem.

This region now contains every large wild mammal, predator or prey, that inhabited it when Europeans first arrived in North America, though not necessarily in the same numbers or distribution. But the wolf is only one factor in the extremely complex and dynamic community of wild Yellowstone.

Life in a Carcass

Since wolves were restored, scientists have discovered layers of complexity reaching far beyond the large mammals. For example, the carcasses of elk, bison, and other large mammals each become ecosystems of their own. Researchers have identified at least 57 species of beetle associated with these ungulate carcasses on the northern range. Only one of those species eats ungulate meat. The rest prey on other small scavengers, especially the larvae of flies and beetles.

Others consume carcass by-products such as microscopic fungal spores. In this very busy neighborhood, thousands of appetites interact until the carcass melts away and everybody moves on.

Wildlife Watching

The northern range of Yellowstone is one of the best places in the world to watch wolves.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar Valley - Wildlife Watching
778 words
There are 3 sections in this description.
Section 1 (249 words)
You are facing the first of two wayside exhibits in front of a low timber fence overlooking the Lamar River. This wayside is entitled "Watching the Wildlife." Text below the title tells us:
"Yellowstone's northern range offers visitors the unique opportunity to observe one of the most diverse populations of free-roaming large animals in North America. Along with this opportunity comes the responsibility of respecting the animals and their habitat. By not disturbing wildlife, we are able to experience them â€˜being wild.'"

Below this text are color drawings of a brown bison and a pair of binoculars. More text tells us:

"View wildlife responsibly. Use binoculars or a telephoto lens to watch Yellowstone's wildlife. Keeping your distance allows you to observe an animal's normal behavior.

"If you see wildlife while driving, find the next pullout, park safely, and watch from inside your vehicle or from a safe distance.

"Do not stop or block any portion of a roadway while viewing wildlife."

A subtitle "Maintain your distance" is followed by more text, including 4 sentences highlighted with bullet points:

"Stay at least 100 yards (91 meters) away from bears and wolves, and at least 25 yards (23 meters) away from all other wild animals.

"If an animal moves within that range, you must move to maintain the appropriate distance.

"Do not surround or crowd an animal.

"If other visitors put you or wildlife in danger, leave the scene and notify a park ranger.


"Animals are dangerous. Never feed or approach."


Section 2 (208 words)

On the panel's right side are two more color drawings showing a black-and-white bird labeled "magpie" and a small brown mammal, or "Uinta ground squirrel." Text beside these drawings reads:

"Never feed wildlife, including small mammals and birds. Human food is unhealthy for them. Feeding wildlife can make them lose their natural fear of humans. This behavior may ultimately lead to the death of the animal."

Below this text is an information box entitled "Prohibited activities within Yellowstone." Three activities are highlighted with bullet points:

"Remaining near or approaching wildlife within any distance that disturbs them. If you cause an animal to alter its behavior then you are too close.

"Viewing wildlife with lights (spotlighting).

"Imitating wildlife calls."

Along the panel's bottom edge are other small drawings showing, on the far left, a park visitor peering into a camera's long lens and, on the far right, a wolf and a bear. An elk and a bison are pictured just left of the panel's center. A dotted line and arrow running from the visitor to the elk and bison is labeled "Minimum viewing distance: 25 yards/23 meters;" a dotted line and arrow running from the visitor to the wolf and bear is labeled "Minimum viewing distance: 100 yards/91 meters."

Section 3 (299 words)

The title of the second wayside exhibit is split into two parts, with the partial title "Stop, look" followed by ellipses in the panel's top left corner and the remaining "and listen" located at the bottom of the panel. The exhibit features large color drawings of three animals-a "Gray Wolf (Canis lupus);" a "Coyote (Canis latrans);" and a "Red Fox (Vulpes vulpes)."

The "Height at shoulder" is noted for each animal, with the wolf's measurement being the tallest at 26 to 36 inches (66 to 91 centimeters). The grayish-brown coyote's shoulder height measures 16 to 20 inches (41 to 51 centimeters), and the smaller red fox measures 14 to 20 inches (36 to 51 centimeters). Text accompanying an arrow pointing to the fox's long bushy tail reads: "Field note: ALWAYS a white tip on the red fox tail!"

In the panel's upper right corner are drawings of the three animal's paw prints; each has four toes with claw marks above the foot pad. The smallest foot pad-that of the fox-is thin and chevron-shaped, while the other animals' foot pads are larger with rounded lobes. Notations beside each print tells us that the Gray Wolf's foot measures 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) long and the coyote and red fox's prints measure 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) and 2 Â½ inches (6.4 centimeters) respectively.

Below the paw prints are three color photos, one each of a lone red fox walking through snow, a howling gray-brown coyote, and a pack of several howling gray wolves.

Finally, text below the "and listen" portion of the title tells us:

"Yellowstone's canids have very distinct sounds. Wolves and coyotes both howl, but coyotes' howls are higher pitched and usually include yips and yelps. Foxes bark, and generally leave the howling to their larger cousins."


END OF MESSAGE

title: Lamar Valley - Wolf Watching

images.altText: Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves. Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.
images.caption: Keep distance from animals

bodyText:
Wolves are highly social animals and live in packs. The pack is a complex social family with older members (often the alpha male and alpha female) and subordinates. Each member has its own personality traits and roles within the pack.

Packs defend their territory from other, invading packs by howling and scent marking with urine.

In Yellowstone, the average pack size is 10 individuals. Around the world, the pack size will depend on the size and abundance of prey.

Osborne Russell (1834–1843)

“We stopped at this place and for my own part I almost wished I could spend the remainder of days in a place like this, where happiness and contentment seemed to reign in wild, romantic splendor, surrounded by majestic battlements which seemed to support the heavens and shut out all hostile intruders."

~ Osborne Russell, explorer in the Yellowstone region, 1834-1843, on the Lamar Valley

Wildlife Watching

The northern range of Yellowstone is one of the best places in the world to watch wolves.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar Valley - Wolf Watching
528 words

There are 2 sections in this description.

Section 1 (252 words)

You are facing the first of two wayside exhibits overlooking Soda Butte Creek. Below you is a footbridge, the start of the Lamar River Trail. Entitled "It Takes a Family," this exhibit features a large color photo of four wolves standing on snow-covered ground. Text below the title reads:
"For years it was believed that the alpha male (dominant breeding male) was the undisputed leader of the pack, and that he alone controlled every aspect of pack life. However, research has shown the pack is governed by a shared leadership between the alpha male and an alpha female (dominant breeding female). Other pack members, although subordinate, are also key to the pack's success as they lead hunts, defend territory and help raise pups."
Pictured to the right of the photo are nine wolves walking single file across barren ground. More text reads:
"Why a pack? Sizes of packs vary, but their purpose does not. Pup rearing, territorial defense, and hunting performance are the ties that bind these complex family groups."
A small photo in the panel's bottom right corner shows a pair of adult wolves and two pups standing beside downed trees. Text to the left of the photo reads:
"Each year, the breeding female makes one of the most important decisions for the pack-she selects the denning site. The den acts like the hub of a wheel during the summer, as the pack spreads out from it like spokes. If she does not choose wisely, the pups may not survive."

Section 2 (258 words)
The second wayside is entitled "Life Begins Underground." Featured on this panel are two large color photos-one of a wolf peering down into a den flanked by fallen trees, the other showing several wolves milling about in a grassy field. Text superimposed over the first photo tells us:

"In early spring the focus of the entire pack revolves around one thing: the den. Inside its dark confines, helpless newborn pups curl up against their ever-present mother and alternate between sleeping and nursing.

"Around two weeks of age, the pups anxiously approach the entrance of the den. As they emerge, the pups are immediately greeted by nearby adults. Lifelong emotional bonds are formed with the pack at this moment."

Text below the photo of the wolf pack reads:

"Stepping Out. Development continues at a rendezvous site. Here, adults alternate between hunting and watching over the pups. Hungry pups swarm adults returning from the hunt, and are rewarded with a meal, reinforcing the pack's bonds. As fall turns to winter the pups begin to grow to adulthood, and take up the arduous task of simply being a wolf."

A smaller color photo in the panel's bottom left corner depicts one adult wolf surrounded by several pups. Text to the right of the photo tells us:

"As the pups grow, play becomes an important part of their development. They stalk, ambush, and chew on patient pack members. These mock battles develop the pups' strength and coordination. They also separate the leaders from the followers, and possibly establish the future alphas."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lamar Valley at Crystal Creek

images.altText: Two mules pull a sled carrying shipping containers and three men
images.caption: Wolves transported by sled arrive in the Lamar Valley (1995)

bodyText:
In the 1800s, westward expansion brought settlers and their livestock into direct contact with native predator and prey species. Much of the wolves’ prey and habitat was destroyed as agriculture flourished. With the prey base removed, wolves began to prey on domestic stock.

Although wolf packs once roamed from the Arctic tundra to Mexico, loss of habitat and extermination programs led to their demise throughout most of the United States by early in the 1900s.

Predator control, including poisoning, was practiced here in the late 1800s and early 1900s. Other predators such as bears, cougars, and coyotes were also killed to protect livestock and “more desirable” wildlife species, such as deer and elk.

Restoration

In 1973, the US Fish and Wildlife Service listed the northern Rocky Mountain wolf as an endangered species. From 1995 to 1997, 41 wild wolves from Canada and northwest Montana were released in Yellowstone National Park.

As expected, wolves from the growing population dispersed to establish territories outside the park where they are less protected from human-caused mortalities. The park helps ensure the species’ long-term viability in Greater Yellowstone and provides a place for research on how wolves may affect many aspects of the ecosystem.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think Safety, Act Safely. Yellowstone is a Dangerous Place.
audioDescription:
Lamar Valley at Crystal Creek
771 words
There are 4 sections in this description.
Section 1 (250 words)
You are standing in front of the first of two wayside exhibits located near Crystal Creek. This wayside is entitled "A History of Persecution." Text below the title tells us:

"As the wave of settlers swept across the Western United States in the 1800s, little room was left for the wolf. With their prey decimated by market hunters and the United States Army, some wolves were forced to dine on the most abundant prey left: domestic livestock. All-out war on wolves began.

"By the mid-1900s, wolves resided in only five percent of their original range. They had been one of North America's most abundant predators, but only a few hundred remained.

"Wolves were not safe within Yellowstone National Park. Park managers at the time saw them as a threat to elk and other hooved animals. Like their brethren outside the park, they were hunted. The National Park Service killed the last known Yellowstone wolf in 1926."

Featured on the panel is a large map drawing of the United States. Most of the country-in all but parts of the southeast- is colored solid orange. According to the map key, this orange area represents "Gray wolf range in the 48 contiguous states before European Settlement." There is also one small orange and yellow striped section due west of Lake Superior, about a third the size of the lake itself. This represents "Gray wolf range at time of listing under the Endangered Species Act (1974)." Yellowstone National Park is marked in green.

Section 2 (153 words)

In the panel's bottom left corner are three black-and-white photos. In one photo a uniformed man carries a newly killed wolf over one shoulder; in another photo, a man stands holding a dead wolf upright on the ground. In the third photo, a man stands in front of a rows of wolf pelts nailed to boards. The caption reads: "Hunters with wolf carcasses and pelts."


On the panel's right side is a large close-up photo of a dark gray wolf with yellow eyes appearing to stare right at us. Below the photo, to the right of a triangular hazard symbol, more text tells us:
"The war against the wolf was fought with more than bullets and traps. Strychnine and cyanide were used to lace carcasses, indiscriminately killing countless mammals and birds. Sarcoptic mange was intentionally introduced into the Northern Rockies by state wildlife veterinarians in 1909 in an attempt to control carnivore populations."

Section 3 (161 words)

The second wayside exhibit is entitled "Return of the Native." Text below the title reads:

"They were once among the most abundant predators in North America, perhaps numbering two million. Yet in the span of two centuries, gray wolves were wiped from over 95% of their range in the contiguous states. Possibly only hundreds remained. By 1926, when the National Park Service ended its predator control efforts, no gray wolf packs were left in Yellowstone National Park.

"In the 1960's Yellowstone adopted a new policy to allow ecological processes, such as predation, to influence wildlife populations. Many felt this form of natural regulation was impossible without the restoration of the wolf. This idea because a reality between 1995 and 1997, when 31 wolves from Canada, and 10 from Northwest Montana, were released in Yellowstone National Park. The wolf had finally come home. In the years since, their descendants have shown the great ability of wolves to succeed when given a chance."

Section 4 (184 words)

A photo in the panel's top left corner shows two people carrying a large crate with a square door pierced with evenly spaced holes. A caption below the photo reads:

"United States Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbit and Director of the United States Fish & Wildlife Service Mollie Beattie help carry the first reintroduced wolf to its relocation pen on January 12th, 1995."


A large color photo in the panel's center depicts a gray wolf standing in profile alongside a wire mesh fence; a wide black collar circles the animal's sturdy neck. In the panel's bottom left corner, handwritten text accompanied with an arrow pointing to the color reads:

"Why the collar? Collars are an essential tool for continued study by Yellowstone scientists. The park offers a unique opportunity to study many aspects of wolves' lives, from distribution and prediction, to reproduction and mortality."


One final color photo in the panel's bottom right corner shows several bystanders facing a truck parked near a large square-topped arch. The caption reads:

"Bringing reintroduced wolves into Yellowstone through the Roosevelt Arch at the park's north entrance."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lava Creek Picnic Area
listingDescription: A picnic area near Lava Creek

images.altText: Picnic tables off a path near a stream in a forested area.
images.title: Lava Creek Picnic Area
images.caption: Picnic by the creek

bodyText:
This picnic area has 5 picnic tables and 1 vault toilet.

Picnicking Notes

Campfires are allowed only in picnic areas with fire grates. Camp stoves (liquid or gas) and self-contained charcoal grills may be used at all locations. Do not feed any wild animals, including birds. It is unhealthy and encourages aggressive behavior. All food, trash, coolers, and cooking tools must be kept secure in a bear-proof container unless in immediate use. Overnight camping is not allowed in any picnic area.

Be Alert for Bears

  • Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
  • Hike in groups of three or more people.
  • Make noise in areas with limited visibility.
  • Do not run! Back away slowly.

title: Lava Creek Picnic Area Trailhead (1N6)
listingDescription: This trailhead starts across the Grand Loop Road from the Lava Creek Picnic Area. The trailhead provides access to the following trails:- Lava Creek Trail- Blacktail Ponds Spur TrailParking and a vault toilet are located at the Lava Creek Picnic Area, though parking can be limited at times. Lava Creek Trail A 4.2-mile (6.7-km) moderate, one-way hike that begins and ends at different trailheads. Either plan on leaving a vehicle at one end, arrange a shuttle back to the start,

images.altText: Bare ground trail leads through some sagebrush covering a field
images.caption: Along the Lava Creek Trail

bodyText:
This trailhead starts across the Grand Loop Road from the Lava Creek Picnic Area. The trailhead provides access to the following trails:

  • Lava Creek Trail
  • Blacktail Ponds Spur Trail

Parking and a vault toilet are located at the Lava Creek Picnic Area, though parking can be limited at times.

Lava Creek Trail

A 4.2-mile (6.7-km) moderate, one-way hike that begins and ends at different trailheads. Either plan on leaving a vehicle at one end, arrange a shuttle back to the start, or plan on hiking twice as far if doing it as a there-and-back hike. Depending on whether you start from the north or south trailhead, Undine Falls will begin or end your hike. CAUTION: Grizzly bears frequent this area.

Blacktail Ponds Spur Trail

An easy 2.2-mile (3.5-km) one-way trail that connect the Lava Creek Trail with the Blacktail Deer Creek Trail.

Backcountry Regulations

Permit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at the Center Backcountry Office: (307) 344-2160.

Hiking

Hike in groups of 3 or more; keep your group together. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to return. Know your route, carry a map, and be able to navigate. Do not hike after dark. Stay on established trails; off-trail travel prohibited in thermal areas.

Fishing and Boating

Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS) inspection required for all watercraft including boats, float tubes, and stand up paddle boards. Felt soles prohibited.

Riding and Packing

Proof of negative Coggins test within last 12 months required.

Food Storage and Camping

These regulations apply to ALL backcountry users. Sleep 100 yards (91 m) from your food storage and cooking areas. Do not leave food, trash, toiletries, backpacks, coolers, water bottles, or any potential attractant unattended. Store food in an approved bear resistant container or hang on a food pole 10 feet (3 m) above the ground and 4 feet (1 m) from sides. Carry a minimum of 35 feet (11 m) of rope. Campfires allowed only in designated campsites within established fire rings. Extinguish campfires completely before leaving site.

 

Follow LEAVE NO TRACE travel and camping techniques. Enjoy the backcountry and help keep it clean for others to enjoy. Bury human waste and toilet tissue in a 6–8 inch (15–18 cm) deep “cat hole” at least 100 feet (30 m) from water and trails.

River Crossings

Park waters are swift and cold. Swimming in park rivers is not recommended. River crossings are hazardous.

Lightning Safety

During thunderstorms, descend to lower elevation, avoid open areas and isolated tall trees. Assume lightning position: feet together, crouch on foam pad or sit on pack, hands over ears.

Regulations

  • Leave What You Find: Do not collect anything from the park.
  • No Pets: No pets on trail. Obtain service animal regulations at backcountry offices.
  • No Hunting: No hunting or discharge of firearms.
  • No Motorized Vehicles: No motorized vehicles on trails.
  • Wheeled Vehicles Restricted: No bicycles, strollers, or wheeled vehicles (except wheelchairs), except where specified.

In an emergency, dial 9-1-1 or contact the nearest ranger station.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

Be Prepared for a Bear Encounter

Grizzly and black bears inhabit all of Yellowstone National Park.

Be Alert: Watch for signs of bear activity: scratches in trees, tracks, scat, or dig sites. Avoid dead animals.

Make Noise: Avoid surprising a bear by calling out and clapping your hands at regular intervals to make your presence known.

Carry Bear Spray: Carry bear spray and know how to use it. Keep it immediately available, not inside your pack.

Hike in Groups: Travel in groups of 3 or more is recommended. Stay with your group at all times.

What to do...

If You Encounter a Bear: Stay calm, do not run. Quietly detour or back away; stop if this seems to agitate the bear. Stay at least 100 yards (91 m) from bears. Do NOT feed bears or other animals.

If a Bear Charges You: Stand still, do not run. Stand your ground and use your bear spray. Spray when the bear is 60 feet (18 m) away or closer. If a bear charges, it may be a bluff charge.

If a Bear Makes Contact: Drop to the ground; play dead. Lie face down and clasp your hands over the back of your neck; stay still and silent. Wait several minutes after the bear leaves before getting up and leaving the area.

listingDescription: A picnic area near the Yellowstone River

images.altText: Picnic tables in a forested area
images.title: LeHardy Picnic Area
images.caption: Picnic in the woods near the river

bodyText:
This picnic area has 7 picnic tables and 1 vault toilet.

Picnicking Notes

Campfires are allowed only in picnic areas with fire grates. Camp stoves (liquid or gas) and self-contained charcoal grills may be used at all locations. Do not feed any wild animals, including birds. It is unhealthy and encourages aggressive behavior. All food, trash, coolers, and cooking tools must be kept secure in a bear-proof container unless in immediate use. Overnight camping is not allowed in any picnic area.

Be Alert for Bears

  • Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
  • Hike in groups of three or more people.
  • Make noise in areas with limited visibility.
  • Do not run! Back away slowly.

title: LeHardys Rapids

images.altText: Small raps across a wide river
images.caption: River rapids

bodyText:
Located on the Yellowstone River, the longest undammed river in the contiguous United States.

In spring, you might be able to see Yellowstone cutthroat trout leaping upstream at LeHardys Rapids. Yellowstone cutthroat trout are the most widespread native trout of the park and were the dominant fish species here prior to Euroamerican settlement.

Some scientists consider LeHardys Rapids to be the geologic northern boundary of Yellowstone Lake because the periodic rise and fall of the rapids appears to control lake outflow.

Yellowstone Cutthroat Trout

  • Require cold, clean water in streams or lakes.
  • Spawn in rivers or streams in early May through mid-July.
  • Most important foods are aquatic insects (mayflies, stoneflies, caddisflies, etc.) and other small aquatic animals, plus terrestrial insects that fall into the water.
  • Also eat smaller fish, fish eggs, small rodents, frogs, algae and other plants, and plankton.

In the 1960s, fisheries managers determined that angler harvest was excessive and negatively impacting the fishery. Increasingly restrictive angling regulations were put into place, which helped restore cutthroat trout population numbers and age structure.

Whirling disease and illegally introduced lake trout in Yellowstone Lake now pose a serious threat to the cutthroat trout population.

They provide an important source of food for an estimated 20 species of birds, and mammals including bears, river otters, and mink. In the recent past, fishing for cutthroat trout has supported a $36 million annual sport fishery.

Fishing Permits

Fishing permits are required in Yellowstone, state-issued fishing permits are not valid within the park.

Permits are available at visitor centers, ranger stations, general stores, and other locations outside of the park.

Visit https://www.nps.gov/yell/planyourvisit/fishing.htm for more information.

 

Be Prepared to Encounter Bears

  • Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
  • Hike in groups of three or more people.
  • Make noise to avoid surprise encounters.
  • Slowly back away from any bears, for they have an instinct to chase.

Accessibility

Visitors with wheelchairs may require assistance due to uneven ground. The southern part of boardwalk has stairs.
audioDescription:
LeHardys Rapids
341 words
You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit overlooking the LeHardys Rapids, which is a cascade on the Yellowstone River. The wayside is entitled "Leaping the Rapids." Text below this title reads:
"In June and July these rapids fill with cutthroat trout heading upstream to spawn near the lake outlet. Spawning is a life-and-death event; here at LeHardys Rapids you can witness the fierce energy it takes for the species to survive. Watch pools at the base of the rapids. A fish jumps every ten to fifteen seconds during peak spawning season in July.
"Crowded with leaping fish, this stretch of river hints at what America's primitive fisheries must have been like."
To the right of this text is a color photo of a single trout with its body rotated slightly, leaping upstream over a waterfall of rushing whitewater. A caption to the left of this photo reads:
"To vault rocky ledges, a mature cutthroat cocks its body, then explodes three to four feet into the air--a height up to five times its length."
A black-and-white drawing spanning the bottom of the panel shows two trout swimming underwater as they approach the shallow rapids. Four arrows--three curling upward and one pointing below the first fish--indicate the motion of water after it descends the falls. A caption above this drawing tells us:
"The force of backwash beneath the falls helps propel fish up and over. At steep ledges many trout appear to fail, but with repeated jumping most of them make it upstream. Far more fish are making the spawning run unseen underwater."
A wood boardwalk gives you access to the whitewater rapids, which span the entire width of the river. The surface of the boardwalk, which is about 5 feet wide with railings on both sides, alternates between flat and sloping sections as it winds several yards down toward the river. There is a long wood bench placed along the left railing a few feet before your reach a viewing platform beside the rapids.
END OF MESSAGE

title: Leather Pool

images.altText: Thick mats of thermophile growth along the sides of the large pool of hot water.
images.caption: Historic view of Leather Pool

bodyText:
Leather Pool was a warm, 139.3°F (59.6°C) pool with leather-like brown bacteria. After the 1959 Hebgen Lake Earthquake, water temperatures rose and killed the bacteria and it was noted to have erupted. Now, it has cooled and once again supports the brown bacteria. It has an average pH of 6.9 and an average conductivity of 1600 uS/cm.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Fountain Paint Pot Area

Hydrothermal features can be grouped into two general categories: those with a great deal of water (hot springs and geysers) and those with limited water (mudpots and fumaroles). Despite their structural similarities, no two features are exactly alike. All of these features occur in the Fountain Paint Pot area.

Thermus aquaticus, the thermophile that revolutionized DNA replication processes, was discovered in this area.

Lower Geyser Basin

The Lower Geyser Basin sits on unstable glacial gravel on top of solid rock. The jarring energy of an earthquake can make the gravel vibrate and shift position, and compact or fracture.

All these changes affect water supplies to hot springs. They might force muddy water to the surface, clouding existing pools or creating new ones. They might divert water from a pool, causing it to dry up. Water temperatures might also increase or decrease due to these subsurface changes.

In the days after the Hebgen Lake earthquake of 1959, all of these changes were observed in various springs of the Firehole River geyser basins. The epicenter (point of origin) of the quake was determined to be about 31 air miles (50 km) northwest of the Fountain Paint Pots area.

Great Fountain Geyser, on the Firehole Lake Drive, is the only geyser outside of the Old Faithful area with eruption forecasts.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.

title: Lewis Lake Picnic Area
listingDescription: - 9 picnic tables- 2 vault toilets (wheelchair-accessible) Picnicking Notes- Campfires are allowed only in picnic areas with fire grates.- Camp stoves (liquid or gas) and self-contained charcoal grills may be used for food preparation at all locations.- Do not feed any wild animals, including birds. It is unhealthy and encourages aggressive behavior that may require management action.- All food, trash, coolers, and cooking tools must be kept secure in a bear-proof container u

images.altText: Picnic tables in a forested area
images.title: Lewis Lake Picnic Area
images.caption: Picnic in the woods near a lake

bodyText:
This picnic area has 9 picnic tables and 2 wheelchair-accessible vault toilets.

Picnicking Notes

Campfires are allowed only in picnic areas with fire grates. Camp stoves (liquid or gas) and self-contained charcoal grills may be used at all locations. Do not feed any wild animals, including birds. It is unhealthy and encourages aggressive behavior. All food, trash, coolers, and cooking tools must be kept secure in a bear-proof container unless in immediate use. Overnight camping is not allowed in any picnic area.

Be Alert for Bears

  • Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
  • Hike in groups of three or more people.
  • Make noise in areas with limited visibility.
  • Do not run! Back away slowly.

title: Liberty Cap

images.altText: People on a boardwalk walk by a dry, tall thermal feature
images.caption: Liberty Cap and boardwalk

bodyText:
Liberty Cap is 37 feet (11 m) tall. It was created by a hot spring that was active in one location for a long time. Its internal pressure was sufficient to raise the water to a great height, allowing mineral deposits to build slowly and continuously for perhaps hundreds of years.

Liberty Cap was named in 1871 by the Hayden Survey because it resembled the peaked knit caps symbolizing freedom and liberty during the French Revolution.

Mammoth Hot Springs

A network of fractures and fissures form the plumbing system that allows hot water from underground to reach the surface at Mammoth Hot Springs. Small earthquakes may keep the plumbing open. The water comes from rain and snow falling on surrounding mountains and seeping deep into the earth where it is heated.

The volcanic heat source for Mammoth Hot Springs remains somewhat of a mystery. Scientists have proposed two sources: the large magma chamber underlying the Yellowstone Caldera or a smaller heat source closer to Mammoth.

For hundreds of years, Shoshone and Bannock people collected minerals from the Mammoth Hot Springs terraces for white paint.

Travertine Terraces

Travertine terraces are formed from limestone (calcium carbonate). Water rises through the limestone, carrying high amounts of dissolved calcium carbonate. At the surface, carbon dioxide is released and calcium carbonate is deposited, forming travertine, the chalky white rock of the terraces. Due to the rapid rate of deposition, these features constantly and quickly change.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.

title: Liberty Pool
listingDescription: Liberty Pool is a hot spring in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: A ring of green algae grows around the edge of the circular-shaped pool, with snow covering the surrounding land.
images.caption: Liberty Pool with algae in winter

bodyText:
Liberty Pool is a good example of the dynamic nature of Yellowstone's hydrothermal systems. This hot spring was hotter in the past and has, for whatever reason, cooled. When it was hotter, the pool has the typical blue waters of a hot spring where only the hardiest of thermophiles can live. Today, it looks less like a hot spring, with algae mats growing across the top and grass growing right up to the sides. While cooler than most other features in the Upper Geyser Basin, this is still a hot spring. The last known eruption happened in 1888.

Liberty Pool has an average temperate of 100.6°F (38.1°C), an average pH of 8.4, and an average conductivity of 1439 uS/cm.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Color & Heat Lovers

Hydrothermal features are also habitats in which microscopic organisms survive and thrive. They are called thermophiles: "thermo" for heat and "phile" for lover.

Although they are too small to be seen with the naked eye, trillions are grouped together and appear as masses of color. They are nourished by energy and chemical building blocks.

Colorless and yellow thermophiles grow in the hottest water.

Orange, brown, and green thermophiles grow in cooler waters.

Imagine living in near-boiling temperatures, in hydrothermal features with the alkalinity of baking soda, or in water so acidic that it can burn holes in clothing. Microorganisms in Yellowstone need these extremes to survive.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: Orange thermophiles line the edges of Liberty Pool and grass grows up to the edge. The clear water is murky near the bottom from plant material.

title: Lion Geyser Complex
listingDescription: A complex of four geysers and three hot springs in the Upper Geyser Basin

images.altText: Snow blankets part of the bare ground and thermophile-covered mound with two geyser cones visible.
images.caption: Lion Group in the winter

bodyText:
The Lion Geyser Complex, also called the Lion Group, is a collection of seven hydrothermal features—four geysers and three hot springs. Though, even the hot springs have a history of erupting. The largest geyser in the group is Lion Geyser, which naturally comes from the largest cone. Lion Geyser actually has a series of eruptions within a single eruption cycle.

Little Cub Geyser was the most frequent erupter of the group, and comes out of the cone on the southern side of the mound. Since 2004, however, the frequency has increased in variety, from anywhere from every hour up to nearly two days later.

Meanwhile, in the center of the group are Lioness Geyser and Big Cub Geyser. Both rarely erupt, but when they do, they reach up to 50 feet (46 m) into the air. Goggles Spring, North Goggles Geyser (no eruptions since 2004), and the unofficially named "Kitten Geyser" round out the major thermal features of the Lion Geyser Complex.

Lion Geyser Complex has an average temperate of 197.1°F (91.7°C), an average pH of 8.8, and an average conductivity of 1979.33 uS/cm.

Geysers

Geysers have constrictions in their plumbing systems that prevent water from moving freely to the surface where heat would escape. Water beneath the constrictions creates a buildup of steam. Eventually the steam pushes water past the constrictions and the geyser erupts.

Hot Springs

Hot springs are the most common hydrothermal features in Yellowstone. Their plumbing has no constrictions.

Superheated water cools as it reaches the surface, sinks, and is replaced by hotter water from below.

This circulation prevents water from reaching the temperature needed to set off an eruption.

Color & Heat Lovers

Hydrothermal features are also habitats in which microscopic organisms survive and thrive. They are called thermophiles: "thermo" for heat and "phile" for lover.

Although they are too small to be seen with the naked eye, trillions are grouped together and appear as masses of color. They are nourished by energy and chemical building blocks.

Colorless and yellow thermophiles grow in the hottest water.

Orange, brown, and green thermophiles grow in cooler waters.

Imagine living in near-boiling temperatures, in hydrothermal features with the alkalinity of baking soda, or in water so acidic that it can burn holes in clothing. Microorganisms in Yellowstone need these extremes to survive.

Upper Geyser Basin

The majority of world’s active geysers are in the Upper Geyser Basin, including Old Faithful. Only four other places in the world have large concentrations of hydrothermal features: Russia (Kamchatka), Chile, New Zealand, and Iceland.

The heat for the hydrothermal features comes from Yellowstone’s volcano. Molten rock or magma may be as close as 3-8 miles (5-13 km) underground. Rain and snow supply water that seeps down several thousand feet (more than a kilometer) below the surface where it is heated.

Underground cracks form a natural plumbing system. Hot water rises through the plumbing to produce hot springs and geysers.

Use Caution in Hydrothermal Areas

  • Stay on boardwalks and designated trails.
  • Hydrothermal water can severely burn you.
  • Never run, push, or shove.
  • Supervise children at all times.
  • Do not scratch hydrothermal mats.

You are responsible for your safety.

Think safety, act safely. Yellowstone is a dangerous place.
audioDescription: A complex of four geysers and three hot springs. The geysers erupt out of sinter cones.

title: Lodgepole Pines

images.altText: Many young pine tree tops and a single burnt tree trunk
images.caption: Lonely burnt tree trunk

bodyText:
Forests cover roughly 80% of Yellowstone and lodgepole pine comprises nearly all of that canopy.

Some American Indian tribes used this tree to make the frames of their tipis or lodges, hence the name “lodgepole” pine. The log walls of the Old Faithful Inn are made with lodgepole pine.

The volcanic rocks beneath much of Yellowstone form nutrient-poor soils. These areas generally have extensive stands of lodgepole pine, which are drought tolerant and have shallow roots that take advantage of the nutrients in the soil.

Lodgepoles are the only pine in Yellowstone whose needles grow in groups of two. They can be up to 75 feet tall. Lodgepole pine trees have very thin bark and can be killed by ground fires.

Fire Rejuvenates Forests

Wildland fire is an integral, dynamic process. Fires rejuvenate forests on a grand scale. Some species of plants survive the intense burning to re-sprout. Some cones of lodgepole pines pop open only in heat generated by fires, spreading millions of seeds on the forest floor.

After fire sweeps through an area, mammals, birds, and insects quickly take advantage of the newly created habitats. Fires recycle and release nutrients and create dead trees or snags that serve a number of ecological functions, such as the addition of organic matter to the soil when the trees decompose.
audioDescription:
Lodgepole Pines
551 words
There are 2 sections in this description.
Section 1 (199 words)

You are standing in front of a wayside exhibit located alongside a forest. The wayside, entitled "Life at the Blowdown: A Flourishing Forest," features a large color photo showing many fallen or uprooted trees lying on ashy ground. A caption on the left side of the photo reads: "The blowdown, after burning in the Fires of '88 (background photo)."

More text below the title tells us:

"Peering into the forest today, you may see signs of raging storms. Ravaged by wind and later by the Fires of '88, the forest here looked devastated. But lodgepole pines are well suited to Yellowstone's harsh climate and volcanic soils. The evidence grows each year."

To the right of the text is a color drawing of two thin lodgepole pine branches, each holding a single cone. One pine cone is longer than the other, with scales that are tightly sealed and greenish in color. A caption reads:

"Many lodgepole cones are serotinous-tightly sealed by sticky resin."

The scales of the second and more-rounded cone are brown and slightly spread apart. A caption tells us:

"Fire melted the sticky resin in this serotinous lodgepole cone, allowing it to open and spread abundant seeds."


Section 2 (334 words)


On the panel's right side are four smaller color photos arranged one above the other. The top two photos are entitled "Beneath Stormy Skies." The first photo is labeled "1984" and shows an aerial view of a deep green forest with one wide lighter green area in its center. A caption below the photo reads:

"A violent wind shear uprooted and toppled thousands of trees here. Seedlings emerged the following spring."

The next photo is labeled "1988" and depicts a charred and smoky landscape where only a few branchless tree trunks remain standing. A caption tells us:

"Four years later, the Fires of '88 roared through Yellowstone, more fierce and uncontrollable than the wind that drove them. When fire reached the blowdown, flames rapidly engulfed tinder-dry logs-and opened cones to release millions of seeds."

The bottom two photos are entitled "Seeds of Renewal." The first photo, labeled "1989,"
shows a handful of visitors walking down a boardwalk trail that passes through a charred landscape. To the left of this photo is another smaller photo offering a close-up view of several red berries hanging from a vine. A caption below the photos reads:

"Lodgepole seedlings, strawberries, and grouse whortleberry emerged the following spring."

The second photo, labeled "1998," shows the same area but now with small green lodgepoles growing among the downed tree trunks. A caption tells us:

"By 1998, ten-year-old saplings had already grown several feet high."

One final color photo in the panel's bottom left corner shows a forest of lodgepole pines, their thick branches blanketed with snow. Below the photo is the title "Lodgepole Life Cycle," followed by text that reads:


"Born in the Fires of '88, the lodgepole pines here are thriving in ash-enriched soil. With serotinous cones on their branches, the trees are prepared for a fiery day in the future-
and will then bear a new generation."

A notation in the panel's bottom right corner reads: "This exhibit made possible by a generous grant from The Yellowstone Association."

END OF MESSAGE

title: Lone Star Trailhead (OK1)
listingDescription: Lone Star Geyser Trail This relatively flat, pleasant 4.8-mile (7.7-km) there-and-back trail follows an old service road beside the Firehole River to the geyser. Lone Star Geyser erupts up to 45 feet (13.7 m) from a 12-foot (3.6 m) cone approximately every three hours.This trailhead is located just east of the Old Faithful development area and Kepler Cascades. It and provides access to one trail (and several other trails further down the way):- Lone Star Geyser Trail- Spring

images.altText: Two visitors looking at the information on the trailhead sign
images.caption: At the trailhead

bodyText:
This trailhead is located just east of the Old Faithful development area and Kepler Cascades. It and provides access to one trail (and several other trails further down the way):

  • Lone Star Geyser Trail
  • Spring Creek Trail (~2.2 miles / 3.5 km down)
  • Howard Eaton Trail (2.7 miles / 4.3 km down)
  • Bechler River Trail (2.7 miles / 4.3 km down)

Lone Star Geyser Trail

This relatively flat, pleasant 5.4-mile (8.7-km) there-and-back trail follows an old service road beside the Firehole River to the geyser. Lone Star Geyser erupts up to 45 feet (13.7 m) from a 12-foot (3.6 m) cone approximately every three hours.

Spring Creek Trail

An easy 8-mile (12.9-km) there-and-back trail that follows a small creek along an old stagecoach route. This is a popular ski trail during the winter season.

Howard Eaton Trail: Old Faithful to Lone Star Geyser

A moderately easy, 6.3-mile (10.1-km) there-and-back trail and heads over a burned hill, through a spruce-fir forest, and to Lone Star Geyser.

Bechler River Trail

A classic, strenuous roughly 30-mile (48-km) one-way backpacking trail in the southwest part of the park that leads past waterfalls and hydrothermal features. The trail starts at either the Bechler Ranger Station or at Lone Star Geyser.

Backcountry Regulations

Permit required for fishing, boating, riding, and overnight camping. More information at the Center Backcountry Office: (307) 344-2160.

Hiking

Hike in groups of 3 or more; keep your group together. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to return. Know your route, carry a map, and be able to navigate. Do not hike after dark. Stay on established trails; off-trail travel prohibited in thermal areas.

Fishing and Boating

Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS) inspection required for all watercraft including boats, float tubes, and stand up paddle boards. Felt soles prohibited.

Riding and Packing

Proof of negative Coggins test within last 12 months required.

Food Storage and Camping

These regulations apply to ALL backcountry users. Sleep 100 yards (91 m) from your food storage and cooking areas. Do not leave food, trash, toiletries, backpacks, coolers, water bottles, or any potential attractant unattended. Store food in an approved bear resistant container or hang on a food pole 10 feet (3 m) above the ground and 4 feet (1 m) from sides. Carry a minimum of 35 feet (11 m) of rope. Campfires allowed only in designated campsites within established fire rings. Extinguish campfires completely before leaving site.

Follow LEAVE NO TRACE travel and camping techniques. Enjoy the backcountry and help keep it clean for others to enjoy. Bury human waste and toilet tissue in a 6–8 inch (15–18 cm) deep “cat hole” at least 100 feet (30 m) from water and trails.

River Crossings

Park waters are swift and cold. Swimming in park rivers is not recommended. River crossings are hazardous.

Lightning Safety

During thunderstorms, descend to lower elevation, avoid open areas and isolated tall trees. Assume lightning position: feet together, crouch on foam pad or sit on pack, hands over ears.

Regulations

 

  • Leave What You Find: Do not collect anything from the park.
  • No Pets: No pets on trail. Obtain service animal regulations at backcountry offices.
  • No Hunting: No hunting or discharge of firearms.
  • No Motorized Vehicles: No motorized vehicles on trails.
  • Wheeled Vehicles Restricted: No bicycles, strollers, or wheeled vehicles (except wheelchairs), except where specified.

In an emergency, dial 9-1-1 or contact the nearest ranger station.

Animals are Dangerous

  • Do not approach or feed any animal.
  • Bison and elk have injured people.
  • Stay 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves.
  • Stay 25 yards (23 m) from all other animals.

Be Prepared for a Bear Encounter

Grizzly and black bears inhabit all of Yellowstone National Park.

Be Alert: Watch for signs of bear activity: scratches in trees, tracks, scat, or dig sites. Avoid dead animals.

Make Noise: Avoid surprising a bear by calling out and clapping your hands at regular intervals to make your presence known.

Carry Bear Spray: Carry bear spray and know how to use it. Keep it immediately available, not inside your pack.

Hike in Groups: Travel in groups of 3 or more is recommended. Stay with your group at all times.

What to do...

If You Encounter a Bear: Stay calm, do not run. Quietly detour or back away; stop if this seems to agitate the bear. Stay at least 100 yards (91 m) from bears. Do NOT feed bears or other animals.

If a Bear Charges You: Stand still, do not run. Stand your ground and use your bear spray. Spray when the bear is 60 feet (18 m) away or closer. If a bear charges, it may be a bluff charge.

If a Bear Makes Contact: Drop to the ground; play dead. Lie face down and clasp your hands over the back of your neck; stay still and silent. Wait several minutes after the bear leaves before getting up and leaving the area.

title: Lost Lake Loop

images.altText: Map of a loop trail with a lake, buildings, and roads
images.caption: Map of loop

bodyText:
Round trip 2.8 miles (4.6 km), moderate.

The trail climbs 300 feet up a forested hillside. At the junction, veer right (west). You reach Lost Lake in 0.2 miles (0.3 km). From there, follow the trail through a ravine to the Petrified Tree parking area. From the parking lot, the trail climbs to a sagebrush meadow, descends to the Tower Ranger Station area, and then 0.2 miles (0.3 km) to Roosevelt Lodge.

If you encounter horses, move to the downhill side of the trail and remain still until they have passed.

Be Prepared to Encounter Bears

  • Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
  • Hike in groups of three or more people.
  • Make noise to avoid surprise encounters.
  • Slowly back away from any bears, for they have an instinct to chase.

title: Lost Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: This trailhead is located at the end of the Pretified Tree Parking Lot. It provides access to the following trail:- Lost Lake TrailParking is at premium at this location, though there also is a high turn-over rate in vehicles. Additional, or winter-time parking can be found in a large pulloff along the Grand Loop Road at the entrance to the parking area. Lost Lake Trail This moderate 2.8-mile (4.5-km) loop trail begins behind Roosevelt Lodge and traverses through forest to th

images.altText: Hilltop view looking over a wide valley, with a road intersection also visible in the valley.
images.caption: View of Tower Junction and Pleasant Valley

bodyText:
This trailhead is located at the end of the Petrified Tree Parking Lot. It provides access to the following trail:

  • Lost Lake Trail

Parking is at premium at this location, though there also is a high turn-over rate in vehicles. Additional, or winter-time parking can be found in a large pulloff along the Grand Loop Road at the entrance to the parking area.

Lost Lake Trail

This moderate 2.8-mile (4.5-km) loop trail begins behind Roosevelt Lodge and traverses through forest to the lake then descends through sagebrush meadows and loops by the Petrified Tree Parking Lot and returns to the Roosevelt Lodge. CAUTION: Grizzly bears, black bears, and bison frequent this area.
